DIV1.P: The Country CAPTAINE, And the VARIETIE, Two COMEDIES, Written by a Person of HONOR. Lately presented by His MAJESTIES Servants, at the Black-Fryers.
LONDON, Printed for Hum: Robinson at the Three-Pidgeons, and Hum: Moseley at the Princes Armes in St. Pauls Church∣yard. 1649.

SP.P: twelvemoneth, thou hast lost thy comple∣xion, by too much study. Why thou shale bee an heire and rule the roaste of halfe a shire, if thy Father would but dye once, come to the Assises with a band of Ianisaries to equall the grand Signior, all thy tennants shall at their owne charge make them selfes fine & march, like Cavaliers with tyltinge feathers gaudy as Agamemnons in the playe after whom thou like a St George on horse back, or the high Sheriffe, shalt make the Country people fall downe in Adoration of thy crupper & silver sturrup, my right wor∣shipfull. A pox on buckoram and the lug∣gage in it, papers defild with court hand and long dashes or secretary lines, that straddle, more then Frenchmen, and lesse wholsome to the client! Is thy head to bee fild with Polamations Rejoyndere & hard words beyond the Alkemist? Be ruld, and live like a fine Gentleman, that may have hawkes, and hounds, and whores; and horses, and then thou art fit Companie.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: You talke wildly; I would you saw your error; that plaee all your happinesse upon such course delights I should degene∣rate, and too much forfeift my education.

SP.SPEAKER: Saek.
SP.P:
Education? hee has gott a tune; I doe not thinke but thou wilt leave thy law, And exercise thy talent in compassing some Treatises against long-hayre & drinkinge that most unchristian weede, yclept Tobacco: preach to the Punies of the Inne sobrietie & abstinence from shaving of leawd Bailiffes
that wil com shortly to your chamber doores & there with reverence intreate your wor∣ships come forth and bee arrested: pretious tad-poles: I would not willingly dispaire of thee; for thy Lands sake and cause I am thy Countryman: one generous vagary, if thou wert wse, would breake som bodies heard, within a seaven night, & then thou art lord of all; have but the grace to dine with me at the Taverne, and I'le tell thy Freinds, there is some hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: My Freinds.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Thy Father is in Essex, if hee live, hee will, purchas Rumford if he dye sooner, then the Town's our owne, Spend but an acre a day and thou maiest live till all the world bee weary of thee; betweene, us too, what thinke you of a wench?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Nothinge.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: You meane, one wench betweene us too is nothing; I know a hundred Leverett; things that will bound like a dancer on the rope, and kisse thee in thy naturall Com∣plexion; a sinner that will climbe thee like a squirrell.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: And crack me as a nutt; I have no kirnell to spare for her sweete tooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: That was a metaphor; he is not de∣sqerate.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Buy' my deere Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Why farewell Countryman. I may live to see thy conversion. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: How does my Vncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Foot.
SP.P: He desires presently to speake with you at his lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I'le attend him. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: And hast thou been carefull of all those thinges I gave in charge to bee provided?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: There is a noate of the particulars.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Tis very well done, Thomas, let mee see, Inprimis.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: The Captaine will not faileto bee with you Sir, hee was not at his lodging, and en∣quiring at the horne Taverne, I heard hee had bin there with two or three cittizens that owed him monie.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: That hee owed monie too.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Tis all one I thinke; Sir; for when Captaines have not pay, Creditors may pay themselves, here they said, he did mollifie the heart of the habberdasher, & dranke him∣selfe a little mellow ere they parted which gave me some hope I might finde him ere night, at the devill, where indeede I fetch'd him out of the fire, and gave him your letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: And the gold too.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P:
That was the first word Hee read, if you had writte it in text, hee could not have fownd it out soe soone, his eye was no sooner on the inside, but his arme flew out with an open month, and his very fingers ends cry'd give me the gold which pre∣suming to bee weight he put into his hocus ocus a little dormer under his right skirt,
and soe taking his word to come downe and turninge over your horse to him, with some caution, not to be drunke and forget your, worship, I tooke my leave and went about my Inventory.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd
SP.P: These thinges are very right Thomas, let me see now the bookes of Martiall disci∣pline.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: I bought up all that seeme to have re∣lation to warr and fighting.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: That was well done; well done; Item the Sword-salve.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Sir if you bee hurt you neede goe no further then the blade for A surgeon.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: The Buckler of faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: You had the sworde before, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: A booke of Mortification.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: I Sir, that is A kinde of killing, which I thought very necessary for A Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Item the Booke of Cannons; Shakspeares workes. Why Shakspeares workes?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: I had nothing for the Pike men be∣fore.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: They are playes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Are not all your musteringes in the Country soe, Sir? pray readon.

SP.SPEAKER: Vad.
SP.P: Bellarmines Controversies, in Sixe Tomes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P:
That I tooke upon the stationers word, who had been Apretty scholler at Paules; for the word Bellarmine, he said, did comprehend warr, weapons & words of defiance words provoake men to draw their swords and fightinge makes an end of the businesse
and all this is controversies, pray goe on Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Two payre of Tables; Tables? for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Oh Sir for Ticktack; you know it was in my note, which though I doubted at first yet consideringe you were newly made A Captaine I conceave it was fitt you should learne to sett & order your men.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Tackticks man; thou didst mistake: they are bookes of warr.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: You cannot know these from bookes as they are painted I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Why doest thou thinke these will make A Soldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Not of them selves, Sir, and there∣fore I provided; please you reade on Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Prsons resolutions; & Felthams Re∣solves.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: All is nothing, I know Sir without resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Somma totalis 23. 19. and 7. thou hast undon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: If you doe not like the penny worthes; Tis but the charges of my selfe and a horse againe to London: I will loose but the three odd pownds nynteene shillings & seaven∣pence. It may bee you doe not understand these Authors; when the Captaine comes, hee will expounde them to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: What a Coxcombe have I to my man? but I dare not bee angry with him, well, carry them into my study; Thoma. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: My most honored Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: My compleate Monsieur Device: This is a grace to us; you come to visite your Mistresse my couzen:

And see as if by instinct, shee had knowledge of your approach, shee is come to meet you: shall I never gett opportunitie with that shee waiter. If I gett her with child my man Thomas shall marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Sir the Captaine is newly alighted.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Get a botle of sack up to my chamber presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: You are a Gentleman of your word.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: And such a Gentleman is to be trusted:

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Hee is an Infidell Madam, that will breake his word with A Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I suspect servant you have many Mi∣stresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Nor by this white hand, I must ac∣knowledge there are some Ladyes in the court in whose eyes & opinions I am favor'd; I cannot obscure my selfe from their observa∣tions: but my heart with contempt of all other indeerements, is only devoted to your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Is it not a charge to dresse your selfe in such varieties of Ribbands every day?

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Is that your scruple? tis the mode to expresse our fancy upon every occasion; to shew the turne, or present state of our hopes or feares in our affections. Your colours, to an understandinge lover, carry the inter∣pretation of the heart, as plainly as wee ex∣presse our meaninge one to an other in Cha∣racters. Shall I decypher my colours to you now; heere is Azure & peach. Azure is con∣stant, and peach is love; which signifies my constant affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: A prettie Morall.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: It saves the trouble of writinge, where the Mistresse and servant are learned in this Amorous Blazon, yesterday I wore fuille∣mote; greedeline; and Isabella; fuille-mote is withered, greedeline is absent, and Isa∣bella is beauty: which put together ex∣prest'd, I did wither or languish for your ab∣sent beautie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: But is thereany reason for their di∣stinctions?

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Yes Lady for example, your fuille∣mote is a withered leafe; which does mor∣rallize decay; your yellow is joy, be∣cause:—

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Why yeallow Sir is jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P:
Noe it is your lemon colour, a pale kinde of yeallow is jealous; your yeallow is perfect joye: your white is death, your milke white Innocent, your Black moorninge, your orange spightfull, your flesh colour asci∣vious, your maid-blush envie, your red is defiance, your gold avaritious, your straw,
plentie, your grasse greene, hope; your sea greene Innocent, your violett, religious; your willow, forsaken.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Wee may then committ a solecisme & be strangely interpreted by some curious ex∣pounders in the rash election and wearinge of our colours, I perceave.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Tis pittie but there should bee some bookes written for our instructions in this Art.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Your Hieroglyphick was th' Aegip∣tian wisdome. Hebrewes had their Caball; the Romans had their symbolle▪ and Im∣prese, & Embleme, but these are absolute. Your moderne Invention of Character, an Alphabeticall key trite and conspicuous your motto or rebus, too open, and demonstrative but the science and curiositie of your Rib∣bands, is not only instructive but an orna∣ment, and the neerest comentator of love, for as love is entertain'd first by the eye, or, to speake more plaine, as the object affected is tooke in first by these opticks, which re∣ceave the species of things coloured & beau∣tified, soe it is answerable to nature that in the progresse of our passion wee should di∣stingvish by our eye the change or constan∣cie of our affections, in Apt, and significant colours.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: You have taken paines, to study this learned Blazon.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: It is the only gentile knowledge; or Phylosophy in the world: I willundertake to open any man or womans heart:—

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Heaven for bidd.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Tell the most secrett imaginations & designes, conclude every passion and scruple if they be but carefull to observe the Artifi∣ciall Method of their Colours.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Why this may bee a way of fortune llinge too.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: You saie right Lady. Physiognomy & Chiromancy are but meere tries your geo∣mancy meere conjecturall, the erection of your scheme circumstantiall, and fallible: but your queint a la Mode weare of your fancy, more then Astrologicall.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Tis a kinde of divinitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: You saie true Madam, & comes neere to propheticall, if the mindes of Ladyes and Gentlemen were elevated to the sublime consideration.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: What paines hee takes to bee ridi∣culous? Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: This Gentleman has a notable fancy, and talkes Poetically.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Yes; yes; hee can make Verses.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Well I have red Authors in my dayes and knew the length of the Poets in my time too which was an Hexameter, and which A Pentameter, but the witts are not, as they have been, right and straight.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Why Drothey.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P:
Why because winde is the cause of many things, now if the winde bee not in the right corner, it is, the ill winde, the proverbe spea∣kes of, which blowes no body good; for whē vapors and winde flye up into the head it
cannot bee in two places at one time and that is the reason your men of most witt doe seldome love A woman. But heere coms my Master and Sir Francis.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Sir Richard; Sir Francis and Master Courtwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: This is a double honnor to us Sir Francis; I shall want Langvage, but not A frendly heart, to entertaine you and your noble Kinsman. What my exquisite Cavaliere Device? Tis to no purpose. I see, to remoue into the Country, to save charges and bee quiet, the whole Cittie will come hither, if I stay: I have no stomack to my court knight. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I hope Madam, you will bee no Ene∣mie to my Kinsman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Sister I present this Gentleman; ob∣serve & cherish him; hee has bin in the uni∣versitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Any degree Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Only batchelour, forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: If he winn you to mariage; Lady Quickfillver.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Hee will bee Master of his Arte.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: My vote is for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I like not the induction of this Rivall.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Hee studies the law: and that is the next high way to preferment, Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Indeede it is the high way in which some deliver up their purses: he may clymbe to searlett, but that hee has to good a face:

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Sir, I hope—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Troth doe not Sir; I meane trouble your selfe, he is to bashfull to prevaile upon your spirited Mistresse. let's leave them.

SP.SPEAKER: Engine.
SP.P: Sir Richard.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: More Customers; Master Engine, welcome. your presence was expected in the Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: Twas my Ambition with some intents to serve you, Sir, please you vouch safe your privacie, I bringe affaires worth your enter∣tainement; I have rid hard.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: What Cavaliere is this unkle?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Hee is the inventor of new projectes ouzen, they saye, and pattents; one that liues like a moth upon the comon wealth.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: He lookes like one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ric.
SP.P: You will excuse me gentlemen. Make much of Sir Francis Madame. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Wee'le leave my Nephew and your Sister Madame: And take A turne in the garden. Exit. with Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: You may bee confident.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I doe not like the fancy in his hat: that Gules is warr and will bee ominous. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I must seeme a modest coxcombe now to preserve my uncles Character.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P:
The Gentleman is turn'd Statue, blesse me how he stares upon me, and takes roote? I thinke it moves, and now to earth is fix'd againe; oh how it walkes and sadly marches
this way? Is't not a ghost? hee'le fright me; oh; sweet Sir, speake if you can and saie who murdered you: it pointes at me: my eyes, ungentle eyes to kill soe at first sight, I'le have my lookes Arraign'd for't & small cupid shall bee judge who for your sake will make me blinde, as hee is.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Lady

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: The man is a live againe and has A tounge, discretion guide it; hee but sent his soule forth of an Errant; tis return'd; now wee shall have some sentences.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Such, are the strange varieties of loue, Such heates, such desperate colds—

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: No more winter if you loue me; un∣lesse you can command the coale pitts; wee have had a hard time of it already, for want of fuell

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.L: I'm all turn'd eares, and, Lady, long to heare you;
But, pressing to you, doubt I am to neare you.
Then I would speake but cannot, nought affords
Expression, the Alphabet's to poore in words.
Hee that knowes loue knowes well that every hower
Loes glad; love's sweete—

SP.SPEAKER: Sist
SP.P: And some times sower;

These wordes would goe well to a Tune, pray let's heare you singe: I doe not thinke but you can make; mee A Jointure of foure Nobles a yeare in ballads, in lamentable bal∣lads, for your witt lyes Tragicall, did not you make the Ladyes downfall? you expresse
a passion rarely, but pray leave your coup∣pletts, and say somthinge in blanke verse before you goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Before I goe; breath not that kil∣linge Langvage;
There is no Sun but in your eyes: and when I once take leave of those Celestiall beames Tis darknesse through the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Oh; pittifull; if I were a widdow then youl'd keepe me waking for feare I shut my eyes, and your discretion loose the way home.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.L: Where strech'don sable grownd, I downe shall lay
My mournefull body, and with foulded Armes:
Heare sadder notes upon the Irish harpe;
And while my Footman playes; sigh out my part,
And drop division with my brinish teares.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: This must bee lamentable musique sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.L: But I will finde an Art to cure this wound;
For I with fancies pencill, will so draw
Your picture in the table of my heart
Your absence shall but like darke shaddowes stand,
To sett you of, and see you, Lady better
Then love wil let me when I looke upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.L: Could this bee true and meant, sweete Sir, to me;
I should be kinder then the gentlest spring
That warmes the world, & makes feirce beasts soe tame
And trees to swell themselves to cheerefull greene
More jocond then the proudest Quire of birdes,
What ere they bee, that in the woods soe wide
Doe singe their merry catches.
Sure hee does but counterfeit. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.L: Oh now I see that love
Is sweete; as flowers in their fragrant birth,
Gentle as silk; and kinde as cloudes to earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: One rithme more and you undoe my loue for ever, out upon it; Peddlers French is a Christian language to this. I had rather you should put me a case out of Littleton: they saye you are a prettie lawyer.

P.HI: Tennant par la curtesy d'Angliterre, est son home prent samme selfe en see simple est fee taile generall en selfe comme heire de la taile especial & ad Issu per la mesme fe∣me male ou female pes on nife soit Issue apres mort ou en diu de la feme debie la baron tiendra la terra durant sa vie per le ley d'Angliterre.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Nay heere is enough in conscience: what a noyse this confusion of Languages makes; this is almost as good as A beare baytinge, harke you Sir, you are never like to recover me by law.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: You are not the first sweete Lady; has ben overcome in common law.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P:
Not by ten thowsand, Sir: Confessed, but I have no minde to come to Issue with A lawyer: when hee should consider my case at
home, hee'le be at West minster teaching men theire statutes! no; no; I will not marry a Judge.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Why Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: They are casuall thinges and men that hold such strange opinions, they are not safe; no, not in their owne lambskins.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Lady you may bee misinform'd; Astraea hath not quite left the earth and the Abuses of some, which shame the callinge, are but like patches of beautie on the face of law to sett the Native whitenesse off.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Farewell; Sir; you are in loue with a bar'd Gowne, not beauty; if you will follow my learn'd counsell, leave it. This younge thinge is a foole or a fine fellow. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Shee kicks and stinges out like a colt unwayd. Her witt's a better portion then her monie I would not love her, yet, if I could helpe it. (My Vnkle and his Mistresse) I'le not hinder them. Exit.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Sir Francis and the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: It is no honour, Sir, if Arm'd with so much eloquence, you overcome A wo∣man; I blush to say I loue you now too much. I wish you would release what your Sweete charmes wonn from my toungue: I shall repent my promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P:
Make me not miserable after soe much blessinge. Why, Madame, it is upon honorable tearmes since not upō the first at∣tempt, but, after a tedious seige to your faire loue, you give up what shall enrich us both:
It were A sinn to feare you can retract what both our lipps have seald, and loose a hap∣pinesse so neere & so secure; your husband holds his pleasure of early huntinge constant, and when hee persues his timorous hart to morrow morninge, Cupid will wayte, to bringe me to Elizium, your bedd, where every kisse will new create us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: You must bee wise in your excuse to quitt his importunitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Leave that to me. I were not worth the name of him that serv'd you to lose my glorious hope for want of such a thin Device; In your thought wish mee prosperous & I am fortified against the power of fate to separate us; and when thou art with in the Amorous Circle of myne Armes, wee will make lawes to love, teach time new Actions, or chaine him with the cordadge of his haire; like a tame thing to wake and watch our pillow; and bee our pleasures centenell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: I see my husband, tis not safe hee should observe us. Bee wise & constant. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: All thats sweete attend thee. Soe; I am saylinge now to my owne Indies: and see the happie coast too; how my winges doe spread to catch the winde which coms to cover them. And the greene sea enamord on my barke, doth leape to see how cupid sits, at the helme & steeres my soule to his new world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: A monopoly, say you, for periwiggs?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Bin visitinge your grounds?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: My hounds rather, Sir Francis, and some horses, that takes up my Country re∣creations; tis Supper time.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: Ist not a rare designe? and by such Art and reasons I can name most beneficiall to the common wealth, preventing the diseases which some unwholesome haire breedes in mens heads. It will bee worth our agitation Sir, & you after the rate of every thowsand per Annum milkt out of the common purse into your owne, may easily defalke to me a hundred for my first projection; did I not love you, Sir, I could make coine of other Abell men that would bee glad to multiply their mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Sir I thanke you, but have no mind to thriue upon abuse of my princes favour, nor the Peoples curse. Heere is a Gentleman; Sir Francis Courtwell, perhaps, will undertake it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: What; Sir Richard?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: A monopoly for composing and sellinge of periwiggs.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Excuse me Sir, I dare not deale in them; doe not you heare things of this na∣ture questioned?

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: How Sir questioned?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: There's one among the rest, I cannot hitt upon his name in faire election to be hanged, one Engine.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: Oh Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: What ayle you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: A meagrim in my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Who's there? looke to Master En∣gine here, hee faints, & send to your Lady for some cordiall waters presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: There is a soveraine well hard by, has done strange cures, please you; I'le throw him into that. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Though I distaste his businesse, I would not hee should miscarry heere, you frighted him. Tis supper time, I shall expect your company in the morninge, Sir Francis: I have a pack of doggs will make the forrest ringe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I'le carefully attend Sir: as early as you please I love the sport too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: I wish wee had all pleasures to delight you; but nothing wants in my true love to serve you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Yet I must cuckold him, I cannot helpe it.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus tertius. Scaena prima.
DIV1.STAGE: Sir Richard and his Lady in Bedd Enter Thomas (with Sir Richards bootes.)

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Who is that? Thomas?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P:
The Sunn is up before you Sir, heere
bee your bootes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: That's well.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Prithee doe not rise, it is hardly day, Sirra, who bid you call him soe early? Sir Richard will not rise yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: I cannot help it, tis none of my fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Where is Dorothy.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Heere, Madame; what make you up soe soone, Thomas.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Oh Mistris Dorothy tis even longe of you for beetweene sleepe and wake your re∣membrance came to me this morninge, and Thomas was up presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: You must excuse me; I meane to kill a brace of hares before you thinke tis day. Come, on with my bootes. Thomas; And Dor thy goe you to Sir Francis chamber tell him the day growes old & I am ready: our horses & our merry houndes expect us. Exit Dorth.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Any excuse to leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: You may take your ease in bedd still Madam, I'le not loose one morninge, that invites soe pleasantly, to heare my Doggs, for a new mayden-head. Twas for these sportes and my excesse of charge I left the Towne; besides the Cittie foggs and steame of brickhills almost stifled me. This Aire is pure, and all myne owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: My Lady meanes shee would have you gett an other Heire Sir for your land, though, it bee against my Master the younge Captaine yet shee speakes but reason and now, I talke of the Captaine, Sir. would you had given him councell.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: To what.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Before hee tooke this huffinge trade upon him to have been a man of peace, I meane, a Justice, nature has made him fits for both a like; hee is now at charge to keepe a Captaine Schoolemaster: he might have sav'd the Quarteridge of his Tutor if I had been his clarke, and then the in come that broaken heads bring in; and New yeares giftes from soadred virgins and their shee Provincialls whose warren must bee licenc'd from our Office.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Away you pratinge knaue; what is hee ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Alas hee's almost dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: How dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Hee has bin troubled with a fitt of the stone Sir, all this night poore Gentleman, hee groanes & sweates & cannot:—

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Make vrine Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: I heard my Lady has an excellent re∣ceipt to cure the stone. Shee is a peece of a rare surgeon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Well-away and gett the horses ready; sirra; or I shall ride you and your witt together.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Alas any foole may ride mee, but I would faine see any man ride Mistris Do∣rothy. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: How Sirra.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P:
I am sorry I must leave such a com∣panion but more lament the cause, I wish
him health: my presence cannot serve him, morrow wife, I will not lose my sport. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor
SP.P: Nor shee; when you are gone; my Lady does expect an other bunts upp

SP.SPEAKER: Dad.
SP.P: Now I must trust thy service.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: You shall not doubt me; Madam; and to assure you my faith, I have a suite to your adiship, whose grant, were there noe other bonds upon me, would tye me to ever∣lastinge silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: What is't; but name it and I shall soone consirme thee

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Our Captaine of the traine band has bin offeringe to chaffer Mayden-heads with me; I must confesse I can affect the foole. upon good tearmes, & could devise to nooze my Amorous woodcock if you assist mee pri∣vatly, and dare trust mee with some Jewell of price, that is not knowne, which shall bee faithfully restored, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: I that dare trust my honnour with thee, shall not suspect thy faith in any trea∣sure else, chuse from my cabbinets, but, prithee, draw the curtaines while I expect this freind, I needs must hide my blushes thou maist discover from my gallery win∣dow when they are horsed, I tremble, to consider what I have promised.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Tremble to meete a ghost; you are more fearefull then a Virgin; Madame; why this setts me a longinge, but I'le watch: this is the timorous world of flesh & blood. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Alas what doe you meane? re∣tire for heavens sake: my husband is not gone, I heard his voice yet, this rash∣nesse will undoe my fame for ever, should hee returne.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Howe's this? retire for heavens sake, my husband is not gone, I heard his voice this will undoe my same. It was my wife and this is sure my bed chamber. Shee lookes out.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: I have undone my selfe, it is my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: My forehead sweates; where are you; Madame; whom did you talke too; or take me for? Ha; a sleepe already; or doe I dreame; I am all wonder; Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Nay; nay kill him; if it please you; sweete heart, I cannot abyde a blacke∣moore Faynes sleeping.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: How's, this? wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Helpe, helpe, deare husband strangle him with one of my lute strings; doe, doe, doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: If shee bee a sleep: shee was nor wont to talke thus, She has had some hideous dreame, shee spake to me, too. Who should I strangle sweete hart, with a lute stringe?

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: The kinge of Moroco I thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: It is soe, shee dreames, what strange chymaeras wee fancy in our sleepe: I were best wake her, Madame, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Oh Murder, Murder.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Sweete harte, Madame, wake.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Tis I.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Sir Richard? ôh, you have delivered mee from such a dreame I quake to thinke upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: I must confesse you frighted mee at first.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: My Master come back? if hee had founde the sick Sir Francis heere.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: How, now, art thou frighted, too.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Frighted quoth a; ô Madame; the key of the closett, quickly, I must have some cordiall water for Sir Francis I feare this will kill him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Alasse good Gentleman make hast.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: His appearance would betray all Thus prevented. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P:
Nay sweete heart, you shall not leave me till I told what a cruell dreame I had, me thought a kinge of blackamoores was in love with me, and havinge, by flatteringe courtship drawne me to his bed chamber, by my consent, or force, swore to enoy me. I knew not by what reasons to divet the Rauisher; but told him that I hearde thy voice, I bid him if hee lou'd his life retire, for thou wouldst, (deare,) revenge my honnour, but hee persuinge mee, I cryd out murther and having nere a sword, I councelld thee to strangle him with a lute stringe; for which cruelty of myne me thought hee threw an Arrowe at mee, which
if thou hadst not wak'd mee as thou didst would, as I slept; with my strong feares have killed me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: This was the kinge of Moroco; well, I am glad I came to take away thy fright.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: But, sweete, you left me, with a reso∣lution to hunt this morninge, have you done already?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: The theeves prevented me, my stable has bin robd to night, two geldings & my Roane ngg are vanished.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Nay doe not thou vex, I have sent Hue and cry that may overtake them; but come I'le leave thee to thy glasse, and visit Sir Francis, now shee is return'd. How does your Noble guest? Enter Dorothy.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Hee is pretty well, Sir Hee has voided one stone since and now findes ease.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Tis well, attend your Mistris. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Oh wench, I had almost undone my selfe, come on the other side, reach me that petticote. I le tell thee the story as I make me ready. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Is it possible you can talke thus, and bee no Scholler?

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I have travell'd in my fancy: tooke the Aire about the world with the muses, and doe for my recreation of witt, compose some wonders in Verse, Poeticall Essaes: as one upon report of a heate that was in Aegipt.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Let's heare them.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.L: In Countryes I have been;
Vnder the Aequinoctiall, where I have seene
The Sun disperse such a prodigious heate
That made our sive-like skinns to raine with sweate:
Men would have given, for an Ecclipse, their lives
Or one whisper of Aire, yet each man striues
To throw up grasse, feathers; nay women too
To finde the winde, all falls like lead, none blew,
The dogg starr spitts new fire, till't came to passe
Each eye became his neighbours burninge glasse.
Leane men did turne to Ashes presently
Fatt men did roast to leane Anatomy.
Young womens heate did gett them selves with child
For none but they them selves, them selves defild.
Old women naturally to witches turn'd
And only rubbinge one an other, burnd.
The beastes were bakt, skin turn'd to crust they say
And fishes in the river boild away
Birds in the Ayre were rosted, and not burnd
For, as they fell downe, all the way, they turn'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Most excellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I have seene Larkes in that motion at fire with an Engine of packthred perpen∣dicular.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: What would they have given for a shower in those Countreys.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Now you talke of a shower, you shall heare another Coppy of Verses that I made of a mightie raine which fell once in the Indies.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: That you made? if you will venture your lungs let me heare some more impos∣sible stories to passe away the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.L: Heaven did not weepe, but in its swel∣linge eye
Whole seas of rheume and moist catharrs did lye
Which so bespauld the lower world men see
Corne blasted, and the fruite of Every tree,
Ayre was condens'd to water gainst their wish
And all their fowle was turn'd to flyinge fish,
Like watermen they throung'd to plye a faire
And thought it had bin navigable Ayre.
Beastes lost the naturall motion of each lymme.
Forgot to goe with practisinge to swimme.
A trowte now heere, you would not thinke How soone
Tane ready, drest for the Empresse of the Moone.
The fixed starrs, though to our eyes were missinge
Wee knew yet were by their continuall hissinge
Women were Mermaydes saylinge with the winde,
The greatest miracle was fish behinde.
But men were all kept chast against their wish
And could comitt but the cold sin of fish.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: And that sinn would puzzell all the civill lawyers in the Kingdome. Sins of the flesh they are perfect in, they know well enough what belongs to Adultery & simple fornication: but you would much improue and oblidge the practice of the court if you could bringe this sinn of fish under their co∣mission. But now I hope the rayne is over; and wee shall have faire weather.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Now can I tell you Lady, what a. strange frost was in one part of the world

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I shall cry out fire if you doe: I'ld rather have some discourse to keepe me warme.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Or how the whole world was trou∣bled with the wind collick.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: No more Earth quakes I beseech you: some frends of myne lost a great deale of Land the last tearme & for ought I know, tis never to bee recoverd. Why all these Verses you have honored me to heare, were translated out of French.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: You say very trew Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Noe, noe; they are out of Spanish as I remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I thinke it bee out of Spanish indeede.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Or else out of the Italian.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Troath Madame; I know not which very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P:
And yet you made them: some Gent∣lemen have the facultie to make Verses, and
forgett what Language, was the Originall. is a la Mode, I confesse, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: There is the mischeefe in Poetry; A man might have told a hundred lyes in prose upon his owne name and never miscar∣ry, but leavinge these lewd Rymes, Lady, how doe you like the Novice that Sir Richard comended.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Master Courtwell?

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Is he not a pretty Chrysome; I could not Choose but laugh to observe in what rurall deportment he came to salute you that should have made his addresse in these postures:—

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: It is enough, Sir, I apprehend what you would doe: the truth is, touching that thinge in black; I doe not love him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I know tis impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Why is it impossible? The man is a prettie indifferent meaninge man but I must have one of a more Active spiritt: noe, noe; the man is a coward.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Hee lookes like one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P:
I put him to it, hee dares not fight, and hee that expects my favor to soe high a degree as Marriage, must bee none of my Lord Mayors whiffelers; he must be valiant in Armes; I am not taken with a ringe or a Carkenett as some avaricious Ladyes: hee that presents me with the sword of his rivall, is more welcome then all the silken soft na∣tur'd 600. a yeare widgeons that will bee baffl'd in their best cloathes; and goe downe into the Country every vacation, like At∣torneys
to bee beaten against the next tear me, & get damages by it. But I forget some affaires that concernes me, & take my leave: your desertes upon mee are eminent and many; and for all your noble services, I will promise you nothing, you apprehend me.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Tis too much, sweete Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I am so weary I can stay no longer with you. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: You make me over happie, soe; soe; the matters done. I may visite my freinds; hum! well thought upon, I shall leaveher Joyes with out any bound to entertaine me, if I first beate this foolish rivall of mine, and present her with his sword; shee assures me hee dares not fight: it shall bee soe, thus with one baffeling and disarminge him I shall secure my Mistresse; and get the reputation of a fighting Cavalier, which may save me many knocks heere after, among men of stronge faith, that shall heae how much honour I have else where taken up upon the Tickett. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P:
Stand right to your files,—Make even your rankes,—Silence—Front to the right hand,—As you were,—To the right hand about,—By the left hand, as you were,—Rankes—To the right, double—Rankes as you were,—Rankes to the left double,—Middle men to the right hand double the front,—Middle men to the
right intire, double the front—Files to the right,—To the left,—To the right hand—Counter march to the right—To the left—Wheele about.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Rantan! enough, you must not, waste your lunges at once; march faire and make a Captaine. When these wordes of command are rotten, wee will sow some other mili∣tary seedes; you beare a braine and me∣mory.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: I hope soe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sact.
SP.P: And now you are chosen a Captaine for the Country, you must give good exam∣ple to your souldiers, and cherish nature: after excercise you must drinke sack; sack is a fortifier. Come wee'le to the Towne.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: With all my heart; Enter Master Court.
Heere is one Master Courtwell let us take him with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: My costiue Countryman; he's an Anabaptist, hee will not drinke, and yet hee kist the cupp oft; last night, me thought, when his mistris dranke to him. Wee'le try; how is't, my man of morall breedinge?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: My man of warr, Tresbone; your servant, Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P:
Why this was spoake like one of us, can'st doe't againe? thy voice is more Au∣thentick, sownds as I have heard a Cavalier in a Taverne; or like the merry Master of the dragon. Smale Neptune, that comptroules the rich Canaries when hee commands the Tritons of his celler; scud and bringe wine you varletts, with a flavour for my Nobil∣litie;
wee were conspiringe to goe to the Taverne.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I'le make one Gentlemen; to wast away some melancholly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Spoake boldly like an Argonaut.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I am not now in London; upon a hall day marchinge with the Puinees Twenty of us in a Teeme, to Westminster in our torne gownes embrodered with strand dirt, to heare the law.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Is not thy Father dead? thou talke'st soe well? how I was couzend' in thee; come a way.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Heere's my man Thomas.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Now the newes, Sir Tristram?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Oh; the Gentleman is mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: What Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Why Master Engine, that did faint last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: With feare of being hang'd for his projections.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: My Vncle told me of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Send him to Bedlam then; what makes hee heere? cleane straw & a good whipp are held restoratives.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Hee walkes and talkes the madliest, twenty midwifes are nothinge to him, hee drownes all their noyce his tonge is twenty ringes of bells; and yet hee seemes soe merry.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P:
Save you Gentlemen; Gallants; Ca∣valeires; how far travell you? me thinkes
you are finely accomodated: are you a doctor Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: No; but I can tell you; how to purge if it please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: You say very well; troth Gentlemen you must pardon me; cry you mercy: your name is Captaine Vnderwi.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Yes, Sir: but my Mother came of the Overmuches by the Peake: she broake my Fa∣thers heart, and Sir Richard buried her. Thinges must bee as please the Starrs.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: What thinke you; of the Blazinge Start in Germany accordinge to Ptolomy? tis very strainge; does the race hold at Newmarkett for the cupp? when is the coo∣kinge, Gentleman there are a parcell of rich jewells to bee sould now if a man had : I doe meane to builde a very fine howse next sommer, and fish ponds. What did you heare of the new play? I am affrayed the witts are broaken, there bee men will make affidavit, they have not hearde a good iest since Taleton died: pray may I craue your name Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.P: My name is Courtwell Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: In your eare, I have a cast of the best Marlens in England: but I am resolve'd to goe no more by water, but in my coach: did you ever see the great Shipp?

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: I have been one of the twentie that have din'd in her Lanthorne.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P:
It may bee soe, shee is a good sailer; but, I'le tell you one thinge, I meane to have the best pack of hounds in Europe, Sir Richard
loves the sport well, and then if I can but finde out the reason of the loade stone, I were happie and would write non ultra.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: The Philosophers stone were better in my opinion: have you no proiect to gett that?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: That has startled him; I doubt this fellow does but counterfeit. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: What thinke you of the Dromedary, that was to bee seene on the back side of the Bell?

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: I have seene a stranger beast.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Soe have I; I have seene you before now, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: Why then I'le tell you; the straingest beast that ever I saw was an Ostriche that eate up the Iron-mines: but, now you talke of birdes, I sawe an Eliphant beat a tailor in the fencing schole, at his owne weapon.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: The Spanish needle?

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: Hee did out eate him in bread, and that was miraculous, I have seene a catta∣mountaine once, but all was nothing, to the Lady, that turnd rounde & threaded needles.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Troth Sir I thinke you have turn'd round too, and are not setteled yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P:
Now you talke of settelinge I knew a Gentleman, that was borne to a great for∣tune, sould all his land, went to sea in a Hol∣lander, was taken by a Dunckercke, at 7. yeares and stole away in a English bottome after that, saw both the Indies, for all this, was taken by a Turkish man of warr put into the Gallies, and, for ought I heare by cre∣dible
report, is not settled yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Sure hee is a great Scholler; a man cannot understand him.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: His braines are out of tune.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: Now you talke of musick; there is noe man in the world loues musick better then I: I'le give you the reason: I have ben deafe almost this halfe yeare; it came with a cold sitting up at Primero.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Now you talke of a cold, it puts me in mind of the new Device of fire, for brewing & baking: had you no hand in that project?

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Againe hee is startled: come hee shall to the Taverne with us and confesse all; if hee does not stripp his soule starke naked to us; say I am no fortune teller.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: What thinke you of a cupp of medium wine?

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: That will spoile all: please you to honnour our society? wee are goeing to Indulge at the Taverne.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: Oh the neates tongues & Asparagus that I have eaten at the Stillyarde! But of all thinges in the world I doe not loue a black catt, next a brewers cart, there is nothing will stay a man soe much in the night as a Con∣stable; one worde before you goe and I beseech you give mee your opinion clearely; was not the Morocco Embassador, a very fine Gentleman for a Pagan?

SP.SPEAKER: Sac.
SP.P: Yes sure; and the Lead mines in Darby∣sheire hold still. Marry for the Allome businesses—But come, will you walke?

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P:
I doe use to goe a foote some times, but
when I ride; and then I must confesse ther's noe striving with the streame: you were in London lately they say the people are more affected to Bearebaytinge then in former time.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: There are some of late are drawen like beares to a stake but for your owne part the goute and the grand pox are all one to you: what price beares meate in the shambles?

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: Flesh rises and fales; as it uses to doe; Sir: But a Country life is the best when all is done: are wee all of one religion? what thinke you of a bridge from Lyon Key to Flandres, you may guesse I talke at randome, Gentlemen, but you must not interpret all foolish discourse a distemper of the braine; Lords would take it for a scandalum magna∣tum, and your Ladyes would bee Angry too; now you talke of Ladyes.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Sir Francis and the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: By noe meanes Master Engine: that Gentleman loues you not. Come, I le bringe up the Reare, where is Thomas?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: I'le follow Sir; I would give my 4. markes a yeare that I could talke like that mad Gentleman; hee's heere, and there, and every where: how will his tongue runn when his Coggs are oyled? they'le drench him. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Although I miss'd a happines, ap∣plaude your nimble witt that secur'd both our honours: you have an excellent instru∣ment to your Gentlewomen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Oh shee deliver'd so toth' life, how you were troubled with the stone, at first I did be∣leive't my selfe, and think of the sad consequence: but time is precious now; although our starrs have not been yet propitious to our meeting, I'le try my Art to night to make them shine with happie influence on our loves.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran.
SP.P: Most excellent, Madam; how?

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: I'le not engage your visit to my chamber, since the first prov'd so unfortunate, but come to yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran.
SP.P: This night? wo'not your husband be at home?

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran.
SP.P: You enjoy but one Bed?

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Without witchcraft Sir. I have a strata∣gem to delude my husband and all his jealous wa∣king eyes: A plot that cannot faile, if you dare but expect me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran.
SP.P: I grow immortall with my hopes, and fancy more than the worlds most glorious Empire, in my first embrace, I should run back into an in∣fant once againe, and by degrees and time, grow up to meet so vast a happinesse: Ages in expecta∣tion spent were poore and easie sufferings weigh'd against this triumph. Me thinks I am not man, but something of a more exalted essence, humane Nature hath not Capacitie to understand and owne these pretious blessings.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P:
No more rapture, but with the confidence of a lover, spread your equall thoughts, and in your heart and Armes Prepare an entertainment for that guest that hath no life nor name but what you give. A kisse, and leave our soules to thinke
upon the joyes this night attends us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran.
SP.L: Sullen day
Doe not tyre now tis down hill all the way.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus quartus Scaena prima.
DIV1.STAGE: A Catch Sung, after which Enter Thomas with a Cloake and a Sword.

LG.L: COme let us throw the dice who shall drinke,
Thine is twelve and his sice sinck.
Sixe and Foure is a cast,
Six and three not too fast.
Come aloft sink tray,
Sice ace faire play,
Cator duce is your throw sir,
Cator ace they run low sir.
Two duces we see,
Duce Ace is but three.
Oh where is the wine, come fill up his glasse,
For here is the man that has thrown Amace.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P:
They are all drunke already, and such a confusion in their heads and tongues: my Master kisses the next man and calls him Mistris Dorothy, Master Courtwell possest with the spirit of defi∣ance to Cupid is ready to beate him for being in
love. My Projector's dead drunk in archaire, and the Captaine peeping into his mouth like a tooth∣drawer and powring down Sack, which he feeles not, but his chapps shut againe like a spring-lock, till he returne with a key to open his teeth to poure in the next health.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: My Cloake and Sword Drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Tis here sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Thou art a pretty fellow; there's halfe a crowne, say I am gone Thomas.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: You are a petty well.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnder.
SP.P: What shalls doe with him? this Engine burnes like Etna.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Throw him into the River.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnder.
SP.P: Hee's able to mull the Thames. VVell for mine owne part, would Mistris Dorothy were here to open her files.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.L: Did not you name a woman?
I will have no mention of any thing thats Femall.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnder.
SP.P: May not a man talke of sack?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Sack is a soveraigne medicine.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnder.
SP.P: Oh very soveraigne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: It is hic & hac sack, both for he and she. Stay, is my Countryman gone? come my Apollos, my Orpheus's, or my Bachus his Minstrells; which to leave poeticall expressions, in broader phrase, is Taverne fidlers, some of your Tunes my masters, doe you heare?

SP.SPEAKER: Musi.
SP.P: Doe you meane Master Adsons new ayres si?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: I sir. But they are such phantasticall ayres as it puts a Poet out of his witts to ryme to them but let me heare—

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: No I doe not like that?—

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Nor that: no, no, no, neither:

SP.SPEAKER: Musi.
SP.P: An't please your worship Master Captain our boyes can sing songs to these.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: No, no, saving your presence, your boyes have nothing surreverence but love songs, and I hate those things monstrously to make things ap∣peare better than they are, and that is but Decep∣tio visus, which after some embracing, the par∣ties see presently what it is.

DIV1.STAGE: The Captaine sings and reeles, Then Phillips all the while with his fingers. (after speakes.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: I, I, this thumping tune I like a lise; a Song, a song to it.

LG.HEAD: Song.
LG.L: The Juyce of Spanish squee'zd grapes is it
That makes a dull braine so full of wit,
So Lemonado's cleere sparkling wine
The grosser wits too doth much refine,
Then to be fox'dit is no crime,
Since thickest and dull braines it makes sublime.
The Stilyards Renish wine, and Devills white,
Who doth not in them sometimes take delight?
If with mimique gestures youl keep you from sadnes
Then drink lustie Claret, twill make you in madnes.
And then to settle you no hopes in beere,
But wholsome pots of Scotch ale though tis deere.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: But harke you child, you say in your song the Devills white, you have been ill catechiz'd boy, for a white Devill is but a Poeticall fiction, for the devill blesse us child is black.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: No Captaine, I say white wine at the De∣vill.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Thats true, thats a good boy indeed—Vnderwit, lend me a peece, lend me a peece to give these harmonious men—Thee,—and now be gone my masters; without noyse, for I will have no more fidle fadles for my money; no tunes of superrogation after the musicall bill is paid,— Exit Musique.
Come hither Thomas, do you thinke I am drunke?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Truely Captaine, I cannot tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: You cannot tell, there's your ignorance, drinke is a vice I am as little given to as another, for I do abhorre it in my selfe, I do wonder how any reasonable man can be drunk, &c—man can be drunke, therefore every wise man take counsell and example by me, and he may see very plaine∣ly what an odious thing it is, for you must follow your Leader, and Vertue which is an ancient—

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Vertue an Ancient?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: I, an ancient old Gentlewoman, that is growne very poore, and no body knowes where she dwells, very hard to finde her out, especially for a Captaine, you will finde it very difficult for a Lieutenant, but we wil endeavour the best we can. You see my courses, I have travell'd to finde her out, and I could never yet see her at a baudihouse?

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.L: VVho is this to be seene at a Baudihouse?
To the righthand—Counter-march.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: He talkes of vertue sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Vertue? she never comes there, why doe you thinke she should be there Captaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Why? because she is an old Gentlewoman, and might keepe the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Alas Captaine Mistris Vertue is poore and leane.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Nay then she is not fit to be a Baud; but tell me, did you ever see her, or if so, did you ever—

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: No, but 'twas none of my fault. I know not what I may doe in time, when she understands the words of command.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: He does not meane Mistris Dorothy; but Captaine, I would aine know the reason why your Bauds are so fatt still?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: A plaine case, they lye fallow and get hart, then they keepe themselves so in health, and so soluble with stewd prumes, and then sipping of sack is a great matter to fatten them. But they are as good people as a man can keepe company withall, and bring up the young gen∣tlewomen so vertuously; I came into one of their houses tother day for a carreere, and I found the Baud very sicke upon her deathbed, very reli∣gious, and much given to repentance, for those poore sinnes she had committed; when shee had taken order for her soule, she told me the young Gentlewoman I look'd for was in the next roome, & desiring her upon her blesting to give me con∣tent, she turnes her to the wall, and gives up the Ghost very privately, because she was loath to trouble us.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P:
By your relation Captaine, these ap∣peere
to bee very good people what if wee went to visitt one of these Matrones? I have a greate minde to exercise

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Why you speake like an understan∣dinge Soldier & one that may come to som∣thinge in the end, therefore let us march on.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: March on to venus warrs.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: For you know, Thomas that the spi∣der & the Bee doe somthinge, but I have for∣gett what it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Tis no matter, come let us goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Goe? no more but goe, though I bee a Captaine if I have not commission in this imploiment,—

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: What then Captaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Why then I cannot goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Very right. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Doe you heare Captaine? for all this; I have a great minde to a wench, and a wench I must have, if there bee one aboue grounde; ôh, ôh; London; London. Thou art full of franke tennants, give me London shall wee wheele about thither, yett?

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Give you London? will not cheapside serve your turne or the Exchainge?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Oh Gentlemen, Master Engine is truly bewitch'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Why, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Bringe the witch and Master Engine before us.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Hee does vomitt the straingest thinges yonder.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Did not I saie, murther will out?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: I thinke hee has eaten and drunken nothinge but monopolyes: and, being too hard to bee disgested they all come up againe, I must hold his head. Within: Oh

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Did not I tell you somthinge would come out?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Pins; Pins; they lay crosse his throat, I told you hee was bewitch'd? Hey day cards and dice, and with them the devill is a gamester. And payes the box soundly, now; now; now: Within: Oh.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: What's that.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Tis somethinge clammy; ôh tis Soape.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Soape? give a man leave to wash his mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Does not the lime burne his throat Thomas?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Alas poore Gentleman, somethinge now againe is ready to strangle him, I thinke they are Hides, & the hornes stuck in his gul∣lett, well straind! what a fowle stomack hee has: Within: Oh.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Open his mouth, thrust downe a pottle pott.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: I have Sir; and it is come up full of medium wine. If you have any charity come and healpe to hold his head: now againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: Oh; Oh; Oh:

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Tis very strainge Captaine; the man is certainely inchanted.

SP.SPEAKER: Eng.
SP.P: Oh; Oh.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P:
Master Master; hey! will you take Tobacco in the Rowle? heere is a whole shipladinge, varietie of Bermoda's and one
little two penny paper of Verina's, with a super subscription, to my very Frends of the cu∣stome howse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Put up that for a relique, Thomas: and open it upon high dayes to cleare the fore eyes of your Spanish Marchants, Thomas; noe more, but call the Drawer, an understan∣ding Drawer and one writes Orthogra∣phy & doe you pay the Reckoninge.

Sirra I charge you set A padlock on the chamber doore: there is a dangerous fellow must be bronght to his purgation and looke all the goods that he hath vomited bee forth cominge. While wee discreetely goe and in∣forme the Magistrates: at your perill Sirra, at your perill: Seale up the dore and doe you pay the Reckoninge.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Sir Richard is a Justice; there's your monie, and yet wee neede not pay; the Gentleman hath left enough for the Recko∣ninge in the next roome.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: I have made him fast; y'are very welcome Gentlemen: all is paid in the Por't cullis. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I'le walke no further; if you have a Secret to impart, you neede not feare this place. The trees, and hedges will not listen, what is the busines? I hope your phlegmaticall stock of verse is spent.

SP.SPEAKER: Cour.
SP.P: Why then in prose the worst that I can speake; I doe not love you Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist
SP.P: How? you have not traind me thus farr to tell me that?

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.P: You are.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: You doe not meane to quarrell, now you have betray'd me to the feild, and beate me, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: What is there in your face more, to attract me, then that red cowes complēxion? why the devill doe you thinke, I should doate upon your person? that thinge when shee is stroak'd gives milke.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: By that I understand, all this is in re∣venge, because you thinke I did neglect you: pray, Sir, tell me, and tell me seriously; put the case that I should love you: could you love againe?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: In troth, I thinke I could not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Doe you but thinke:

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I will binde it with an oath before the parrish.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: What reasons?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I shall bee loath to say your eyes are twinckelinge starrs againe your lipps twyn cherries, and out bluh the rubies; your Azure vaines vie beautie with the Saphire: or that your swellinge brest are hills of vo∣rie pillowes for Joue to rest his Amorous head. When my owne conscience tell me that Bunn—hill is worth a hundred of them, and but High gate compared with them is a para∣dice, noe I thanke you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sst.
SP.P: But how come you so curd? you weere a passionate, I may saie, foole, in hope you will deserve it: what phisick tooke you, that hath thus restor'd you?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: A little sack had power to cure this madnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I hope you are not sober yet; the hu∣mour may chainge when you have slept.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I'le rather stich my eye lids up with Sisters-threed, and stareperpetually.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: When you may see me againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I thinke I shall not, unlesse it bee to wonder when you are in that vie bush; that face cutt upon taffata, that creame & prunes soe many plumbes in white broath, that Scut∣cheon of pretence. powderd with Ermines. How sell you grapes? your haire does curle in bunches: your lipps looke like the Par∣sons gleabe; full of redd, blue, and yellow flowers; how they are chapp'd and looke like trenches made to draine the medowes?

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: This rudenesse is beyond the manner of a Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I cannot help it and I hope you thinke soe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: But if your passion have not drowned all reason; I pray let us part civilly.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.P: With all my hart, I dare then take my leave too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Whoe is that.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Where.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Behinde that tree.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: You have no plot t'accuse me for a rape? t'was at the worst, but fellony with cherryes, that looke as if they had bin a fort night gathered:

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I know you'le bringe mee home in curtesie.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Not I; I will not trust my selfe and you: fare well Lady: doe you see that bull?

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Yes Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: That is a happie beast.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist
SP.P: Why happie Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Hee writes noe verses to his Mist∣resse, is not cozened nor forsworne: to get her favor, bestowes no rings, nor empties his exchequer to appeere still in new rich suites but lives free upon the stock of nature, yet loues none. Like the great Turke, hee walkes in his Seraglio and doth command which Concubine best pleases, when hee has done, hee falles to graze or sleepe, and wakes, as hee had never knowne the dun, white, redd, or brended Cow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: You are unmanly.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Nay, I know you will raile now: I shall like it: call me a skirvy fellowe, proud, and sawcy, and ill bred crooked clowne, I'le heare. This, rather then liue upon your pittie, and yet doe not: For if you raile too men that know you can dissemble, may beleive you loue me, and tis not my Aime.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: You are a fine man

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I am in my best cloathes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I perceive tis true now, what the world sayes of you, and yet tis strainge.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Tis strainge it should bee otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Sisst.
SP.P:
You give your tongue a licence, nor will I hope your mallice should spare me a broad, that have soe prodigally abused a Ladyes fame that deserves nobly from you; but you men care not whose name you blast
with a loose Character, soe you maintaine your pride of Talke.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: How is this? it is confessed I have talked in my time and talked too much, but not too much of you; for I but seldome thought of such a woman, or any other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Nay Sir I am satisfied, you can talke your pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Have I not done it, too?

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Yes by your owne report, and with a Lady soe much in vertue & in birth aboue you? & therefore I expect not your modest language of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Stay. This moves me; I never tooke a pleasure yet to lye with Ladyes fames: or ever thought that sport lye in the tongue; such humors are for men: that live by Bro∣thell offices, let mee but know who hath traduc'd me to you thus, hee shall bee known noe more.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I'le not bee guilty Sir: of any murther; when wee meete againe and you in better humour I may tell you: so farewell Gon∣dario, nothinge's lost when you turne wo∣man hater. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: She has vex'd me, if wee two make a matrimony after this rate, the divell is like to dance at our Wedding. Enter Device.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Hee's heere, a lone too, and the place most opportune! how shall I begin. Master Courtwell, doe you loue any friend of mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Not to my knowledge, Sir, I should bee sorry.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Doe you not loue a Gentlewoman, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: If shee bee a frend of yours, I'le take the first occasion to neglect her, for your sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: It will become your wisdome, and your safetie.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: What mischeefe have you done to your face?

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: My face?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: You looke soe scurvily, come hither thou new monster, with more feete then a caterpiller what time of the day is it? you that move upon soe many wheeles, say Mon∣sieur, are you not a walkinge clock; I have a mighty minde to see you tooke in peeces.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I doe not like this: you cannot put me, Sir, together againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I will not take the paines, why doe you smile now?

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: At your conceit, to thinke I was a clock I am a watch; I never strike, Hee's valiant. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: You have prettie colours theire are these your Mistresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: If you did know the mistery you would applaud them: you have read Lievre de B'azon, what meane you?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I will bestow them upon some fore∣horse; they will become a Country eeme rarely.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Morr▪de! why you dare fight it seemes, and I was told, you were no Cava∣lier: A very dreame, a wedge for men to breake their swords upon, I shall never trust fame againe for your sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Thou never didst couzen me.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I was never soe Illitterate in a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: For did ever thinke thou durst not fence but at a cōplexion, aglisteringe vapour: a thinge of cloathes, and fitt for Chamber∣maydes to whett their witts upon: but now resolve either to have your skine flead off; or fight with me for troublinge my present me∣ditations.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Why Sir if you bee serious I shall quitt that prejudice you have upon my valour looke you Sir I can draw, & thus provoke'd I dare chastise you, too cause I was merry I am not bound to feede your spleane eter∣nally with laughter, yet I am not Ignorant what an advantage, Sir, your weapon gives you in length.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Wee'le change why this is honnour in thee. They measure and Device gs both weapons.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Now, Sir, keep of.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Sure thou art not so base.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I never cozend you, doe you remem∣ber? these two will guide me on the rope.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: You meane to daunce then.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Yes but with quicker time then you I hope can follow. Thus I begin; fa la, la. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: What a heathen coward is this? how the rogue tripps like a fayrie: to the towne with them, he has bin a footman sure I have not breath enough to overtake him, & t'will be darke presently if I loose the sight of him; I'le search the Towne and if I finde him not there, persue him with hue and cry, and after hange him. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: The sun, whose busie eye is still Employed a spie upon our Actions, tire'd with waytinge is drowsy gon to bed, about whose pillow night hath hunge all her winges, & set up Tapers as if the day were timorous like a child and must have light to sleepe by, welcome all the howres that go∣verne pleasure, but bee slow when you have blessed mee with my wishes, time and loue shall dwell like twinnes, make this your bower and charme the aire to sweetenesse, and to silence: favour me now, and you shall chainge your states: Time shall bee old no more, I will contract with destiny, if hee will spare his winges, to give him youth and beautie, that wee may finde every minute a fresh childe of pleasure: loue shall bee proud to bee no more a boy but grow to per∣fect strength and hold consistance: for when two active lovers meete soe happie as wee whose equall flames doe light Embraces twill bee noe weight to number many yeares in our delights and thinke all age a blessing: but language is too narrow to expresse what I expect, tis fit my soule retire till shee pre∣sent her selfe, and if it can measure my hop'd-for Joyes with thoughts prepare to entertaine the happinesse. Exit.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Dorothy (with a light) to Sir Richard & his Lady, (in bedd)

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P:
I have sett already my designe a
moveing to take my Captaine, Vnderwit, who in wine was late more feirce uppon me; in the meane time I cannot choose but laugh at the Device wee hope to cheate my Master with sure the devill is agreat freind to womē that loue men! Hee doth so furnish us with quainte inventions: presently after supper, shee began her sit of tooth atch, and did coun∣terfet so naturally; but since shee went to bed she almost rau'd by turnes; I heard her at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Oh oh; whose there.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor
SP.P: Tis I for sooth, I heard you groane and I have not the heart to sleepe, shall I watch by you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Oh no! get you to bedd, make fast the chamber: I cannot endure.—

DIV1.STAGE: Droib puts out the candle at the dore and returnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Deare heart, bee patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: I, you have your homilyes of pa∣tience, but if you had my paine, it would make you mad, oh; oh.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: I'le send for the french tooth drawer in the morninge.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: There is no rack nor torture like it, oh; what shall I doe; I shall never sleepe againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Which tooth is it.

SP.SPEAKER: Do.
SP.P: The sweete one you may bee sure troubles her

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: This, this; oh that there.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: They are happie that are old and have no teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Oh take heede; now it shoots up to my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Thou makest my headāke with thy noise.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: If you knew what I suffer, your head would ake, in deede, I must rise and walke in the chamber, there's no remedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser Rich.
SP.P: You'le catch more cold.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Oh noe; deere life doe not crosse me; if you weere in my torment, you would rise; and try any thinge, for a little ease It cannot bee worse the paine sure came with a cold and who knowes but an other cold may cure me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: I prithee come to bedd againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Soe, soe doe not trouble me. I am now in some little ease it is a heavenly thing to bee goeing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Doest thou heare?

SP.SPEAKER: Lad
SP.P: Your noise will bringe my paine back againe, if you knew what a vexation it is for me to speake you would not put me to it soe, if you doe talke I will not answere a word more. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Rich.
SP.P: Well! by this noe light I'le to London to morrow. I see tis possible a wo∣mans Tooth may bee as trouble so me, as her tongue

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Oh; oh.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: I cannot chuse but pitty her: that any woman should hold soe much paine in a hollow Tooth!

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P:
If my Master touch'd with soe much compassion should rise and force me to bedd
to him, I must not cry out a rape. Tis at the worst on my syde, but fornication in my owne defence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Prithee come to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Oh; oh; oh:

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: The musick at a convocation of catts, at a witches upsittinge is the spheares to this catterwawlinge. I will thrust my head into the pillow, as Diana did, in the bush when the beare was cominge, and then I shall not heare her.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Oh! this is a kinde of purgatory for the sines of the flesh: if she should fall a sleepe with the other knight; it is not possible I should hold out till morninge that which would fright away an ague hath put mee into a feauer: I shall have the tooth atch in deede with counterfeitinge. I have knowen some men taught the Stammers so, my gumes doe murmur, there is feare all over my flesh shee will stay too long, and then,—

SP.SPEAKER: Ser Rich.
SP.P: Vh; uh:

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Oh; oh; I'le shift places to shew more distraction at the worst my noyse shalbee within his reach it may give her warninge to returne too. Exit.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Lady to Sir Francis (a sleepe) a table Inke & paper set out.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P:
I am full of feares and my owne motion frights: me this furious love is a strange Pilott: Sir where are you, ha; a sleepe? can any dulnesse that is not death possesse a Gentleman so valiant in desires, when hee
expects to meete his Mistresse? how I blush to rayse him? was I not worth thy wakinge expectation, farewell: yet somethinge like a chaine that's fasten'd to my poore heart re∣straines me, inke and paper: Writes.
I'le leave him a short monument of his shame & my neglected love. Hee knowes my hand, farewell forgetfull lover. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.

DIV1.HEAD: Actus quintus. Scaena prima.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I cannot forgett my carelesse Gentle∣man; his neglect & reproches have wrought strangly upon me; hee's heere.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Is there not a weazle crept in to your chamber, Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: A weazle Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Yes, a Monsieur suckegg.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Doe you take my chamber for a hens nest, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Ther's a Thinge that calls him selfe Device, one that will break the heart of a post-horse to continue a hand gallop with him, your a la mode, your fightinge fayrie, fethered footed servant, when saw you him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: My fightinge servant, has hee beaten you Sir? perhapps hee thought you were his rivall: surely I saw him not since yesterday.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Be'e Lady how many mile is it to the next Cutler? the rogue has pawnd or sold my sworde.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Doe you heare Sir? I can tell you now what Lady; it was you did abuse so

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I abuse a Lady? Tell me the slave re∣ported it; I hope it will prove this Monsieur if ere wee meete againe;—Who was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P:
Vpon condition Sir you will requite
me but with one Gentle favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Any thinge.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: You must sit downe and heare me then, while lat a distance, thus deliver.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Tis more state.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I am most unfortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: For what deare Damosell?

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: And wrong d by a Gentleman I lou'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Can hee bee a Gentleman that dares wronge so much love and beautie? what s the offence?

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: He will not love againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: And you would have the stubborne man corrected?

SP.SPEAKER: Sist
SP.P: I would bee revenged, if I know how, and honour him, should doe me ustice.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Name the man: I'le doe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: How.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Yet turne your face: alas! it is your selfe: I have your word to punish him.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Sweete Lady I am well acquainted wih the worthy Gentleman, but will not kill nor strike him: for I know hee has just reason not to love you, you, of all your sexe; hee told mee so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: His reason?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P:
Was in these words, suppose you heare him speake it. Now doe you sit; Lady; when I consider you to a perfect forme of what we can call handsme with all your at∣tributes of soule and body where no Addi∣tion or detraction can by cupids, icer critticks finde a fault, or Mercury with your
eternall frame & then consider what a thinge I am to this high Character of you; so low so lost to noble merits, I dispaire to love a Mistresse cannot love againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: This is as much dissembled modesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: No let it all alone, I have other rea∣sons, Lady, among my papers, to love, or to bee in loue is to bee gull'd, that's the plaine English of cupids latine besides, all reverence to the calling, I have vowed never to marry: and you know, loue may bringe a man to▪t at last and therefore my fine gewgaw, doe not abuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: How can I when you will neither loue me nor marry mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I was not made for a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: But I would make you.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I know what you would make me.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Monsieur Device if you bee alone would present his service to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Is hee come?

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Doe me but one favour, I'le recant my loue, I will not have so much as one good thought of you, I will neglect you, Sir, but for three minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I'le have patience so long. He hides.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Admit him. I will bee revenged on somebody? now Sir: Enter Device.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I'have broug'ht you a weapon Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Me, what to doe Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Tis justice I present it to your feete, whose love Arm'd me to vindicate your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: My honour?

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: This is but the first of my valour in your cause; if you affect these monuments, I'le make you up an Armory: meane time receive my service with this sword; if hee provoake me to fight with him againe; I'le cut his hand off and bringe it with me, to present the next.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Whose hand deare Servant?

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
