SP.P: Hee is not worth the naminge, alas; this does not deserve your knowledge; only thinke what I dare doe, when your bright name is questioned: and I in time may mer∣rit to bee call'd the darlinge of your Virgin thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist
SP.P: Pray stay; my name traduc'd? who was so impudent? doe me the grace to let me know on whome your valour has bin exer∣cis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Why upon the formall thinge, call'd Courtwell, I would call him Gentleman, but that I have baffled him; you neede noe other witnesse then his sword: Shee shuts the doore. With the fine holliday hilt.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Looke you Sir I have made fast the doore because I meane before you goe, to have a satisfaction for the base Injury you have done me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I done you Injury?

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P:
Not that I value Courtwell whome you would pretend has bin too saucy with my honour, but cause I scorne to owne a good∣nesse should depend upon your sword or vin∣dication: I'le fight with thee my selfe in this
smale volume against your bulke in folio.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Excellent wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I was your champion, Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I had rather have no fame then have thee name it; thou fight for a Ladyes honour, and disarme a Gentleman? thou fence before the Pageants & make roome for the porters, when like Elephants they carry once a yeare the Cyttie Castles: or goe a feastinge with the drum or schole boyes to the banke syde & save the beares a whippinge that day: come Sir I meane to have about with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: At what weapon?

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: This, and none other, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I'le rather bleede to death then lift a sworde in my defence▪ whose inconside∣rate brightnesse may fright the roses from your Cheekes, & leave the lyllyes to Lament the rude divorce: but were a man to dare me, and your enemie, my rage more nimble then the Mdian shaft should flye into his bosome, and your eye change Anger into smiles, to see me fight and cut him into a rag∣ged staffe.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: I cannot hold no longer; you have got a stomack Sir with running, I'le try how you can eate a Sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev
SP.P: Have you an ambush Lady; I'le cry out murther, tis two to one. Faire play!

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Let me but cut one legg off to marre his running.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Hold: let me speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: What canst thou saie for thy base∣nesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Some men love witt, and can without dishonour endure a Ieast; Why? doe you thinke I knew not you were heere & but ob∣serv'd to see my humour? I came to wayte upon you with your sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: How came you by it? Confesse be∣fore this Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Doest thinke her witt's so lymber to beleive I could compell it from thee, twas a trick, a meere conceipt of mirth, thou shalt have myne: Doest thinke I stand upon a sword? I'le give thee a case of pistolls, when wee come to London; and shoote mee when I love thee not: pox on it, thou apprehendest me well enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: But I am not satisfied, doe you loue this Gentlewoman?

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Hum;

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: You will resolve Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: As may become a stranger; I will not lose thy friendshipp for all woman kinde.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Hee dares, not owne you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I easily forgive him: I should hate my selfe if I depended on his pitty.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Thou art a noble wench: shall wee leave of these Jiggs, and speake our minds in earnest by these twyn lipps, I loue thee extreamly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Sweare by your owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: They shall bee myne: Monsieur, for your pennance you shall a long & witnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: What I pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Cou.
SP.P: The priest shall tell you, come, wee have both dissembled, wee doe loue one an other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Tis not possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Vnlesse you will denie me in the church. I have vowed to lye with you this night: Device, amble before, and finde the Parson out; wee will bee frends, and thou shalt bee her Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: I must mayntayne my honour, or be beaten.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: Com we'le have no more acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Very pretty! I may deceave you yet for all your confidence.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: If the skye falle, wee'le have the darkes to supper. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Lady Sir Francis and Dorothy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: It was a strange neglect, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I confesse it, and not deserve to live for it, yet if you but knew my sufferings.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Let her bee Judge.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: By no meanes Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: You may trust her knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: This is worse then a whippinge now, these Ladyes have no mercy on a delinquent; I must stand to it; there is no tyrant to a chambermayde, made judge in such a case; I'le give a limbe to bee quitt now; but if shee chuse, I am a criple for this world.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Is it possible? A man and such a beast?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Soe: I must to the shambles.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: What punishment can bee equall to the offence?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P:
Hee lookes with some compunction for his fault, troth, Madame, such an other
night: and trye whether hee'le sleepe againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Mercifull wench; if wee piece againe; it shall bee a good turne in thy way.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: My husband is resolu'd this day for London. It is his humour, or else worse, suspition: there's noe pretence for him to stay behinde.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: You have made ill use of your time Sir Francis; I know not how to helpe you; seauen yeares hence you may have such an other opportunitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Watch if my husband come not this way, Dorothy, well Sir, though your trans∣gression deserve no pardon, yet I am chari∣table upon condition.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Any thinge, Madame: this shewes ex∣cellent in you. No pennance shall displease, so you absolue me. Bid me to clyme some rocke or piramide, upon whose narrow speare you have advanc'd my peace, and I will reach it, or else fall lost to the world in my contempt.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad
SP.P: You speake gloriously, the condition that assures your pardon, is only this, that you conclude, here, all your loose desires, with a resolve never to prosecute or hope to enjoye me:

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P:
Call you this charitie, let me rather loose your pardon, then ever bee thus Di∣vorc'd: binde me never to see you, (and yet that were cruelty) then, charme me to forget that I am man, or have a heart, and you a beautie which your absence can as well make nothinge, as divide from my adoreing
It is not cure but killing to prescribe I never must enioye you, if you have resolu'd death upon me, let it bee when wee like lovers have embrac'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad
SP.P: It is not possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: nothing in loue can bee impossible to willing mynds. I'le tell you, Madame, Sure the devill has forsworne the flesh, there may bee a plott, I have it. An excellent rare Do∣vice, if you but favour it: your husband is immediately for London I must in modesty ride with him; you are left behinde.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: How can that proffit you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: What a deale of submission these foolish men trouble us women with, that are more forward to bee frends againe, then they?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I will counterfeit a fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: A fall?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I, from my horse, observe me then.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: My confederate I hope by this time is at the gate enquiringe for Sir Richard very formally from the old Knight his Master & good Lady: the follow has witt to mannage it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: My Fo man shall pretend himselfe the surgeon to attend me; I'st not rare? stand but to it fate in this and if I faile I will sit downe a convert and renownce all wanton hope hereafter. Deerest Madame if you did meane this honour to me before let not your louinge thoughts freeze in a minute; my genius is a prophet.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Sir Richard, Madame, is cominge this way.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran
SP.P: Shall I hope againe

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: I will not say you shall dispayre.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: You blesse me. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: My businesse is on foote, your Jewell Madame will credit much the cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Wee will with draw; and let me know how you, have cast the plott. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Sir Richard (openinge a letter) & Footman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: From thy Master? his name?

SP.SPEAKER: Foot.
SP.P: Sir William Litleland.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: I doe not know him.

SP.SPEAKER: Foot.
SP.P: His name is well known in Lincol∣neshire neere the Fenns; there were of his family Ancient Gentlemen before the con∣quest, some say, ever since the flood,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Little Land?

SP.SPEAKER: Foot.
SP.P: But hee has now more land then 3. of the best of the sheere, thank the dutch men that have drunke up al the water.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: They water—drinkers?

SP.SPEAKER: Foot.
SP.P: Why not, as well as eate dry land? they are lyn'd with butter; Sir; they feare noe dropsies.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.

P.HI:
Shee has bin absent these two yeares, the occasion her dislike and disaf∣fection to a Gentleman whome I confesse, I did severely urge her to marry, if shee have liv'd with you, as my late intelligence informs me in the nature of a Servant, which is beath my wish and her cōdition, I hope upon this knowledge, you will with consider of her qualittie shee beinge my
only child and heyre to my fortunes, use her like a Gentlewoman: and though my pea∣res have made me unfitt for trauell I doe Intend upon the returne of my daughter, whome I shall receive as a new blessinge from you, to expresse my selfe for your favour

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your trew Frend and Servant WILLIAM LITTELAND.

SP.P: My maid Dorothy A knights daughter & heire? doe you know your younge Mistrisse?

SP.SPEAKER: Foot.
SP.P: I shall bee happie to see her, with a Letter and token from her Lady Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: I pray trust me to deliver it.

SP.SPEAKER: Foot.
SP.P: I, With all my heart, Sir; you may command.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Tomas, pray entertaine this Foot∣man in the buttery: let him drinke & refresh him selfe and set the cold chine of beefe be∣fore him hee has runn hard.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: That will stay his stomack indeede; but claret is his only binder.

SP.SPEAKER: Foot.
SP.P: Sack while you liue after a heate, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Pease you, I'le shew you the way to be drunke. Exit with Footman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: To my lovinge daughter? may not this bee a trick? Enter Vnderwitt.
By your favour Madame; Captaine, gather you the sence of that Letter, while I peruse this, you know Mistris Dorthy?

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P:
I have had a greate desire to know her,
I confesse, but shee is still like the bottom of the mapp, Terra incognita, I have ben a long time hoveringe about the Magellan straytes but have made no new discoveryes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Ha! This is no counterfeit; I dare trust my owne Judgment; tis a very rich one I am confirm'd, and I will seale them up againe. My Ladyes Woman Sir William Littelands daughter and heyre? what say you now of Mistresse Dorothy?

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: A great deale better then I did, and yet I have loud her this halfe yeare in a kinde of way, of my conscence, why may not I marry her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: This Jewell was sent by her Mother to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Deare Vncle conceale it till I have talke with her, oh for some witchcraft to make all sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: I like this well: shee's here.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: I vow, Mistresse Dorothy; if I were immodest, it was the meere impudence of my sack, and not my owne disposition but if you please to accept my loue now by the way of marriage I'le make you satisfaction, like a Gentleman in the point of honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: your birth and estate is to high and unequall for me, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: What care I for portion or a face, shee that has good eyes, has good—Give me vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: You are pleas'd to make your mirth of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: By this ruby nay; you shall weare it in the broad eye of the world; doest thinke I jest?

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Sir Richard:—

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: If hee were ten Sir Richards, I am out of my wardship

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: How hee flutters in the lyme-bush: it takes rarely. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: What a necessary thinge were a hous∣hold chapline? Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: So; so; the wench inclynes, I will hasten my jornie that I may appeare with more excuse, when they are married in my absence. Exit.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Master Courtwell, Sister and Device.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Come wee are fast enough, and now I have thee, I'le tell the all the fault I finde, thou hast a little two much wit, to bee a wife: it could not bee too nimble for a Mistresse. There is a part of your pennance still behind Device; you would pretend to bee a poet, I'le not disgrace the name to call thee one, but let me have times against wee goe to bed, Two Anagrames that weigh an ownce with coment, and after that, in verse your affida∣vitt that you doe wish us joye, and I'le dis∣charge you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Tis time I were at study then.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P:
About them, your double congie, and depart with silence: now prithee tell me who reported I had wrong'd a Lady? Was it
not thy revenge to make me Angry?

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: It was indeed Now tell me; why at the first approach seem'd you so modest? you have confidence to spare, now.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Troth I came not with any wooinge purpose: only to please my Vnkle, and try thy witt and that converted me. Enter Tho.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Did you see my Master Captaine Vn∣derwit?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Yes he's talkinge with a priest and Mistresse Dorothy.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: Her Fathers Footeman is heere, shee is a Knights daughter and heyre, but shee doth not know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: I thinke soe?

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Where's my Vnkle?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: A myle on his way to London, by this time with Sir Richard, I longe to see my Master. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Wee shall want Companie to dance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: My Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: If you please Madame, you may call me, Brother, wee have ben at, I Iohn take thee Elisabeth, a possett and foure naked thighes in a bed to night, wee'le bid faire earnest for a boy too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sist.
SP.P: Tis even so Madame; the Priest has done it

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Nay then all joyes attend you; if this had bin knowen, it might have, stay'd Sir Richard, and your Vnkle one day more.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Roome for an other couple.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: In hell, my Master is maried.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: My husband left some letters, and a token was sent you Mistris Dorothy, you did Ill to obscure your selfe so much, you shall not want hereafter all respects that may be∣come you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr
SP.P: Madame I know not what you meane.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Shee will not take it upon her, yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: There is the sport Enter Device.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Oh Madame, newes; Ill newes; an Accident which will blast all your mirth, Sir Francis;—

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: What of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Has broake;—

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: His neck?

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: You guesse very neere it, tis but, his shoulder has sav'd that Joynt; a fall from his horse they saye hath much endangerd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: My Vnckle hurt? Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Hee has kept his word; now if hee counterfeyte handsomely.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Monsieur Device, I must entreat a cour∣tesie: you have wit and I will have a Masque to entertaine my new Father in Law Sir William Littleland; Mistris Dorothy now my wife is his only daughter & heyre

SP.SPEAKER: Dr.
SP.P: Who has gull'd you thus? I am no Knights daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Dev.
SP.P: Give you Joy Captaine

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Shee is still loath to confesse it.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Sir Francis; Master Courtwell, Lady, Sister, Sackbury.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: If you loue charitie; a bone setter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Hee counterfeites rarely, where is Sir Richard.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Hee rid before, but I sent my Foote∣man, to tell him my misfortune; oh; Ma∣dame.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: This is better then the tooth atch; he carries it excellently.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Aske me no torturinge questions, I desire Madame a little conference with you, I'le thanke the rest if they will with draw.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Lett's leaue him.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Wee'le to my chamber, Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: You have a minde to examine the bu∣sinesse privatly.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd
SP.P: No, good Captaine you may bee pre∣sent, come; Thomas, thou shalt bee wittnesse too. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: They are gone, you faine most Arti∣ficially, let me embrace you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Oh take heede.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: What's the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Tis noe dissembling, Madame; I have had a fall indeede: a dreadfull fall, I feele it, I thinke my horse sawe the devill in some hedge, ere I had rid three furlongs: gaue a start, pitch'd me off his back like a barre and broake a flynt with my shoulder, I thinke; which strooke fire too there was somethinge like it in my eyes; I am punished.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: But is this serious, are you hurt in∣deede?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P:
Hurt? I have broake my shoulder, feelingly, and I am of opinion when I doe enjoy you, Madame, I shall breake my neck: that will bee the next; I'le take this for a
warninge and will leaue of in time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: It makes me tremble.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I will bee honest now, and so forgive me, is not the surgeon come yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: Heaven hath cur'd us both.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: I am not cur'd yet, oh for the bone setter, if ever I counterfeit againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: There is a blessing falne upon my bloud: your only thoughts charme had power to make my thoughts wicked, and your con∣version disenchants me: may both our liues be such as heaven may not greeve, to have shewed this bountie.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Courtwell and the rest with Sir Richard.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Sir Richard; Madame:

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: You may enter now, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: I doe not like this Stratagem, Sir Francis must not heere practice his court tricks, I will not trust my wifes surgery:
Hee's come; Sir Francis is led out.
How is it noble Sir Francis; best with draw, I'le see him drest my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Madame and Gentleman; Mistrisse Drothy will not acknowledge she is a Knights daughter she sweares she knowes no Little∣land.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: Till it appeare to whome, this emm was meant, deafe Madame, bee you treasurer, I confesse I have wealth enough in such a noble husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: It shall belonge to thee; be honest Dorothy, and use him well.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr.
SP.P: With my best study, Madame;

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Where is this Fooman you talke of?

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: He petended letters to carry two myles off to a Kinsmans of his Masters and returne presently: hee drunke 3. or 4. beere glasses of Sack and hee rune away so lightly.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: His reward shall overtake him.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Will you have her; shee'le doe you service, Captaine at a low Country leager or thou Thomas I le give thee a coppihold.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: You have one life to come in that lease yet, I thanke you I am free, and that is Inheritance. For ought I know shee may serve us both.

SP.SPEAKER: Sack.
SP.P: Come you may persuade her to take it upon her for your creditt, the gullery is yet with in these walls let your shames goe noe further, the wench may prove right; shee may.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: What newes from Sir Francis.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Wife I hartily aske thy forgive∣nesse: I had jealous thoughts, but all is right againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.P: I will deserve your confidence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: No greate danger, his blade bone dislocated: the man has put every thinge in his right place

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Doe you heare Sir Richard, wee are married.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Tis well done t'is to my mynd, send you Joy;

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: Come hither Dorothy.

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: My Mother dyed, I have it by tradi∣tion, soe, as soone as I was borne my Father but no Knight, is now in the Indies a poore Marchant that broake for 20000.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: The ships may come home, ha;

SP.SPEAKER: Dor.
SP.P: You had best use me well now wee are married, I will bee sworne you forc'd me to the church and thrise compeld me there to said, I Dorothy—The Parsons oath and mine, for ought I know may make it halfe a rape.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: There is no remedy wee can proue no conspiracy; and because I have bin gull'd my selfe, gett her with childe; my Doe is barren, at birth of hir first baby I'le give thee a hundred peeces.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: That's somewhat yet: when charge coms on, thy hand, a wife can bee but a wife: it shall cost me 500. but I'le make thee a Laay in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: How is it Sir Francis.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: My Surgeon sayes no danger: when you please I may venture Sir to London.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Noe hast now.

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Not to night, Sir, wee must have revells, and you salute my bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Vnd.
SP.P: And myne.

SP.SPEAKER: Tho.
SP.P: A Knights daughter and heyre.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P:
May all Joyes thriue upon your Ioues; then you are cozen'd of your Mist∣resse Monsieur, but your nephew knowes
I have met with my match if not put to the worst.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Rich.
SP.P: Come wee loose time.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Preserve your Marriage faith: a full increase of what you wish confirme your hap∣pinesse.

DIV1.P: THE VARIETIE, A COMOEDY, Lately presented by His Majesties Servants at the Black-Friers.
LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Moseley, and are to be sold at his Shop at the Princes Armes in St. Pauls Church∣yard. 1649.

LIST.ITEM: SIr William, A Sutor to the Lady Beau∣field.
Master Newman, A Sutor to Mistris Lucy.
Formall, Gentleman-usher to the Lady Beaufield.

DIV1.HEAD: Act I. Scaene I.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Sir William (at one doore:) Mr Manly (at the other.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sr. Wil.
SP.P: I Ack Manly, well met.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Noble Sir William the hum∣blest of your servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr. Wil.
SP.P: Come, thou shalt along with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Whither?

SP.SPEAKER: Sr. Wil.
SP.P: To see my Mistris.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: May you thrive in your courtship to her: at this time I am engag'd to other business.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: Can any thing concerne a Gentleman equall with a handsome Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Yes, the receiving of money is more considerable with me at this time, than all the women in the world. But who is your Mistris Knight?

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P:
I dare tell thee, Madam Beaufield, the
Lady of spirit, and entertainment, the only Mag∣netick widdow i'th Town.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: They talk her a wit, and a most supersti∣tious observer of persons, and their garbes; I ne∣ver had the happiness to kiss her hand, or be known to her, but I converse with some who are very high and loud in her character; another time Enter Jeere Major, and Minor. Ile wait upon you. Who are these?

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: In what grott hast thou spent thy time, that thou art ignorant of these people? These two are held the wits; That is the remarkable Jeerer of the Town, and 'has purchas'd to himself the title of a Jeere Major.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Why, Is there a Regiment of Jeerers?

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: You shall pardon me, there are sets of them, as there are of Fidlers; there is first a set of Court Jeerers, spruce half-witted men, con∣fident, and fierce in their opinions; these are men that make themselves musick, and their cloths make roome for their wic; and go before in all compa∣nies: Then there is the town Jeerers, like Ho∣boyes or Waites of the City, that think they are wise when they are loud, and make a noise when they come to Plaies, to distract the next mans understanding. There are Jeerers at time of the yeer that go down into the Countrey, and in∣fect Wakes, and Faires, and the Sizes, with their impudence, with which they save charges, and are never without the name of a great Lord, to whom they are cosin Germane.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: But what has he deserved to be called Jeere Major, and to beare such a title? I have seen the Rooke.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: An excellent ill nature has preferd him to opinion: the other has merited but the name of a Jeere minor; yet they can see me pleasant in their reproaches, and laugh in their own defence, which many times keeps off the cudgell.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Nay, Jeering is a blessing that every man may have if he give his mind to it: but wit (if I remember what I was taught) happens not to one amongst five hundred on 'em. But I forget my affaire.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: Shall's meet and be merry this Evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Theres no musick in me without my sing∣ing birds about me, then I am a Lord, and when I put on my habit of Leister, I am his own excel∣lence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: Dost thou preserve that him or still?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: I may chance by the false light of the Evening march to thy Lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: Dost know where tis? I am remov'd. (whisper.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: So, no discoveries what Prince I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: A match: that shape will beget us some mirch.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Your most humble servant. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: My Mistris is somewhat melancholy, if he come in that phantasticall habit, we shall have rare sport beyond his expectation, to have the La∣dies laugh at him. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: This is very fine wit ysaith, and soone learnd I thinke; a little more on't sweet Gentle∣men.

SP.SPEAKER: Jeer.
SP.P:
Suppose you were foxd last night; thus I come to you, and accost; Save you Sir; you must
know I must laugh all the while; how fare you Sir? Do not some fumigations remaine, some va∣pours not dissipated, a kind of Vertigo, a weak∣ning of the Nerves, or so? Ha, ha, ha, what thinks your Worship of milke now, thin broth, or a Julip of pitifull Six for a penance to settle you, or a haire of the same whelp? Ha, ha, ha, there's wit for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: There's no harme in the world in it, nor no exceptions if you laugh in the right place.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: Now imagine you met an honourable Gentleman that had got a hurt in the groine; thus I invade you; but the laugh must hold me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: By any meanes, I cannot choose but laugh my self.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: There is no safe jeering without it.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: Sir, you have been at push of pike and received a hurt, upon some unslaught in some fe∣male service, Ha, ha, ha; your breath is Aroma∣tick since you kiss'd your Mistris, and your water out-smells the violet, ha, ha, ha; by the powerfull—yclipped Turpentine, tis true; what pitty tis you went without a charme, or had no acquaintance with a Laplander, to make you Venus-shot-free? Ha, ha, ha; and how many french tennistalls have you in your flanke now? ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: You sate up at play all night, and lost your money; another now.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Not I a penny, I sent a buffe Gentleman that lookt big upon me, after an ill hand, twenty peeces upon halfe a dozen oaths.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P:
A good pawne, keep his oaths, if he do not pay your money, take the forfeit, and if he be
a Gamester he'll be undone for want of swearing.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: Suppose it lost?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: Me thinks Cavallier you looke pale since you came from the charnelhouse, did the bones affright you? you are a most religious Gentleman when you are at dice, and do so pray for 3 fives 3 foures at in and in: with what devoti∣on you look on the seven of Spades and eight of Diamonds at cribbish? ha, ha; how zealouly you invoke the Saints to fit you with cards at picket, or lebet.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: I invoke the Saints?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jer.
SP.P: I speake to the catholicke gamester, that understands all games.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: By the way though, doe you think there are any gamesters in heaven?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: It is to be feared, they may lose so much upon earth, they will hardly purchase a place there, or if any get thither, (which must be excellent throwing) he would be more call'd upon, and perhaps puld downe agen, upon every dispute at play to be Groome porter.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: How like you these?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: You shall both with me to my Mistris, and help to Jeere my rivalls.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: Your Mistris?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: I Mistris Luoy, Lady Beaufeilds daugh∣ter, my Landlady Mistris Ʋoluble has commend∣ed me to her, and I hope to carry her, if one Gentl. that she loves better do not get her away?

SP.SPEAKER: Ambo.
SP.P: Wee'l jeere him to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P:
That were an excellent way, I thinke there is no statute against that, I care not what becomes on him, he put bitter jests upon me to∣ther
day before the Ladies, and I making use of your wit Gentlemen, he told me to my face, that I talk'd nothing but clinches; as I am a Gentleman he did.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: Oh barbarous!

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jer.
SP.P: You shall wound him with his owne weapon, and by a direction we can give you, you shall so jeere him, that he shall offer boote to change understandings with you.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: Wee'l make him so ridiculous, he shal laugh at himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: That will be rare; I have sent for my Mother to towne to be acquainted with La∣dies, and learn dressing; my Landlady, hath pro∣mised to commend a Gentlewoman to waite upon her, and teach her the art of painting, and all the postures of a great woman; I do meane she shall marry some Knight or other, and be Ladified.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: It wil be necessary.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Though I say it, the woman is flexible, and has been in her daies—My Father might have been a Knight, and he had not been an Asse, and lov'd his mony; but we lose time, let's to my Mistres Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Both
SP.P: We attend sir. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: The same day, a Dolphin taken in a net at Woolidge, and ten live Pilchards in a Salmons belly—strange things! the 13. of July, the Caramountaine kittend in the Tower: an Eele∣ship spring a leak shooting the Bridge,—heere are prodigious things. Enter Newman.
Mr. Newman.

SP.SPEAKER: New
SP.P: Mr. Usher, how does your Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: She is in health.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: And Mistris Lucy?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Both in the Garden. Sir you have good intelligence, what newes abroad? a touch to your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Alas you are acquainted with the state mysteries.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Troth Sir, I know little, or if I did, I would be loath to speake it, but to a friend, the times are dangerous.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Y'are right Mr. Formall, but be not nice, I know you are furnish'd with newes, as well as some that give pensions, though 'twere to a Cap∣taine in these warlike-times, to have it made for 'em; you being a quotidian ambler upon imperti∣nent visits, must needs gleane the secrets of the court and state.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Sir I dare trust you with any thing, but pray do not speak on't; there is a great man in the world—

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Think you so?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: That—

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: What has he done?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: You shall excuse me; but—

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: VVhat his name?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: You shall excuse me for that too; a word to the wise; you can guesse what I meane, and let that passe; and now we talke of state af∣faires, there is a packet come out of the North, and abox—in your eare sir.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: What is said to be in that packet?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Ther's the businesse, but that no body knowes.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Is't possible?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Tak't upon my word; you are a friend, I heare further at Mr. Secretaries, but you must say nothing of it, you undoe me if you doe, the King goes to Hampton Court next weeke, but how long he stayes is uncertaine. Sir, you see I put my selfe into your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: But is this done like a wiseman to reveale these mysteries, to trust these secrets to one you have not known above 7 Yeare, if I should inform what will become of you, and your estate? oh you must be cautious, though for my part—

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Oh Sir! I know to whom I speak, and will tell you more, for I dare trust you with my soule; they say the Northerne progresse holds this yeare, and that the Elke is dead in the new great parke

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: I hope not.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Tis as I tell you, by the fall of a tree, doe not you remember a tempest foure nights agoe? then 'twas, blustring times Mr. Newman.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: That makes Ʋan Trumpe so troubled with the winde colicke, but now the Hollanders, as they report, have many Engineers and Ma∣thematitians set a work, how to keep and vent it at their pleasure, and so to serve in Navigation for their ships, that there may be ventus liber, as well as ventus clausus, answerable to the two Seas.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Ha, ha! that's newes indeed, alas mine is but domestick, but what do you heare of London Bridge? it is whisper'd by some it will, and some againe point blank say it will not be repaired; but make not me the Authour.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P:
And I do heare the Camells decay at
Tiballs: but pray no more of it from me.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: You shall not doubt me Sir, you do not heare of the Dolphin—

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Of France?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Taken as Woolidge in a net.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Of Italian cutworke.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: The newes is not common of the Pil∣chards, the Catamountaine, nor the Eeleship?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Not a word.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: You shall heare more; I am your servant. Here is Mistris Lucy Sir, and Mistris Ʋoluble.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: I confesse he has no overcharge of wit, that will be your happinesse, he has a good estate, and you may live with more delight than a court Lady, he is a handsome man too, I am bound to give you my advise, for your mothers sake, whose servant I am by many obligations, she has been my customer for face-water, and pomatum these many yeares.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: But if you be so skilfull, as you are profest, and read in the secrets of nature, you can tell by your art where I shall fixe my affection, doe not you know Mr. Newman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: I never see the Gentleman, but I am not ignorant that he matches in the Vanne, and leades the file of your amorous servants, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: But what?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: If you love your selfe.—

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: He is a well-bred Gentleman, and one deserves my good opinion, hee's here.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: They observe me— Exit Form:
I kisse your hand faire Mistris Lucy: whats she that lookes so like one of the Sibills?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Is this the Gentleman you declare so civill, and well-bred, Lady? If I have any skill take heed on him, he has an unlucky countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: This Gypsey will but cozen you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: She is excellent cunning, and has foretold str ange things, beleeve it.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: If my Mistris have an opinion of her Art, she may do me a displeasure; I have heard much talk of this woman, some say she is a Witch too, and weares the Devill in her thumbe Ring, I would not anger one of her Familiars. Take no of∣fence Mistris at the rudenesse of my Language, this Lady shall give a very faire pawne, the word of a Gentlewoman, that I shall be of good beha∣viour, if you please not to interpret me too ha∣stily.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: There is some texs in your forehead Sir that wants a comment, but Ile not so much study your satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Nay, thou shalt not be displeased with him.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Lady Beaufield, and Sir William.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Alas, I am not angry; heres my Lady and Sir William.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: You are Master of an excellent language Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: You honour me too much, it is because you are the excellent Subject Madam, and being the perfection of your Sexe, an argument to create Eloquence in every tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau
SP.P: Then I must think you flatter; these prai∣ses are misplac'd. I shall suspect you love me not, or are not wise.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: Why Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: You take such paines, and make a pilgri∣mage to thats within your reach; I must confess I like Discourse, but think not all my soule plac'd in my eare; although I love a Lute well, it fol∣lows not I should dote upon a Cimball.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: A Cimball?

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: And dance as I were stong with a Taran∣tula, when you are at it, rosting of a Galliard? You overdo this instrument, give me your courtship in a phrase is fit to own and understand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: Your pardon Madam; I affect not bold and over-rack'd Hyperboles, although I might in∣sist upon the wealth and fulness of your merits, to which, all praise, that can flow from me, is Ju∣stice, such command you have upon your humble Servant, I rather wish my tongue a forfeit to per∣petuall silence, then with one harsh sound offend your eare; you'l give me leave I hope to say I love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: This is English Sir, and some do call it sence; 'tis faire, and fit, when any Lady's private with her Servant; 'tis what I learn'd a child, I have not yet outgrown the knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: Did you love so young?

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P:
I understand the meaning of your lan∣guage, 'tis not perplext, and you may love me too, and tell me so, and I may understand you; what need compartments here, freeses, and words of Architecture, that will make things hard to the un∣derstanding? As you could not build a sence in love without 'em? Yet I bar not the freedom of Dis∣course, and use of Metaphors: And you may praise us too in Verse, or Prose, to shew the exal∣tation of your wit in company, but 'tis the worst
discourse when we are private.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: If I had confidence she would direct me—action I beleeve when opportunity In∣vites—

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: To what good Knight? be not mistaken, I commend courtship in words, that are made round like pills fit to be swallowed, and not rag∣ged bullets.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: 'Tis a strange Lady, I know not how to take her.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: My Lady? Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Art thou come?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Is it your Ladiships pleasure I shall read to day?

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: By any meanes, the Ladies will not faile, we should forget our Academy: Sir William we must entreat your patience, and Ma∣ster Newman. Vol. whispers to Sr Wil.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Madam, the Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Say I wait upon 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: Ile take my opportunity.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: You will engage him to credulity, and prepare some mirth.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Mounsier Galliard the Dancer attends Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: He must give way to another exercise; Sir William you shall do us a favour if you please to entertaine a little time with him in the next Chamber, our Lecture will not be long, and sweet Mr Newman the French-man will delight you with his discourses, he has a tongue as confident as his feet, if you can but humour him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: You shall command us Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: That Done wee'l joine societies and mirth. Come Mrs Voluble.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: I hope you will excuse my imperfecti∣ons. Exeunt.

DIV1.HEAD: Act II. Scaene I.
DIV1.STAGE: Table and six Chaires set out. Enter Lady Beaufield, Lucy, and other Ladies, Mistris Voluble.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P:
IT is an infinite favour, (most excellent Ladies) and must needs speak the sweet∣ness of your nature and dispositions, that y'are pleas'd to hear me, so weak and un∣worthy of the Chaire, rather deserving to be in the number of Disciples, than a professor in any of the female sciences; but as your ver∣tues are more exemplary, in this honour to me, the humblest of your Servants, it will become me, in the gratitude to so noble a bounty, not to waste time, but succinctly to deliver, what I could not finish without trespasse on your patience; at my last reading I did conclude with old Ladies, that will cozen Nature, and Time, and abuse the men they love best; to these I only add, it is not Mercu∣ry to change their skins like Snakes, but they must fill up wrinckles as well as hide gray haires: your red leather is for Countrey Wenches, your white wash, or Spanish Fucus is the best, but a tire wo∣man,
or coverer of time or nakedness must be kept in pension: sor it is now fashionable to buy one of her apprencice Girles out of her time, as Lords and Gentlemen do Barbers boyes. Amongst other ornaments, Ribbands challenge no meane place, the variety, and blason of these, I have elsewhere examined. For your finest Laces, the Angel in Cheape, but they must be dearer then o∣thers, because they come in Coaches, for pride or stateliness in any thing adds charges. Touching Gloves, might I advise, I would have a few select∣ed Ladies, to procure some ingenious Gentleman at a reasonable pension to lye Lerger for them at Rome for Frangepane Gloves, and such other cor∣respondent things as may be of moment and great consequence to your Ladyships: But then I must advertise, and most seriously, that he may be a man of parts, and somewhat smelling toward the Roman Wash, that he may give you intelli∣gence of that State, and humours of the Gardi∣nals, or those that pretend to it, be they little or great, for this concernes the state Ladies here: For your swarfie Mountebanke Italian, he utters sophisticated Holborne Gloves for Frangepane, Esse Cheese for Parmesan, rotten post for sweet powder, pickled white Leather for Mushromes, and cozens more with his broken English, then the wits can get honesily with their best language.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Lady
SP.P: The Merchant of Italian Saulsages, A meet Quack.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P:
But then I would advise your Ladiships to have another Gentleman sent into Spaine for perfumes, pocket Fannes, orange flower water, Orange flower butter beauty, Aqua de Chedrey,
and many provocatives, as Contra yerua, and Joco lata.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Lady
SP.P: It is a very learned Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: For Holland, 'tis too deare in Spaine, there∣fore for a conscionable cozenage over and above, here are honest Dutchmen will serve you most faithfully. For Jewels, you may buy them at what rates you please, they add lustre to a Lady, and you may sell them at a fift or sift part, which is very well for a great Madam, if you would put them off at the best rate, you must get some Do∣ctor of Phisick, or broking Apocriphall Captain, to shew them (as if there were fornication in it) behind the doore, hanging or curtaine, which makes his fingers like Jewellers cardes to set rings on, for there are bawdes for rings and Jewels, as well as for other commodities.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: What do you think of this caution Ma∣dam?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: For your Linnen, it must be fine, and fresh every day, therein consists humane delight. For linnen breeches, though some think them cleanly, in my opinion they imitate a Dutch Stove too much. For Aprons, plaine Holland is most be∣comming, starch'd Lawne was in Queen Elizabeths time, and will not endure rumpling, every thing must be squar'd by use and elegance; but for your white Shoes, rich Roses, light-coloured silk Stock∣ings, and such variety below staires, they are great Inducers, as a learned man told me, (I will not say a Divine) for Love, most excellent Ladies, doth sometimes ascend, as well as descend.

But still remember Ladies, that your Fanne be so little, as not to lose the least smirke, or grace
of your countenance for it, for then being so small, when you put it to your face, some Courtiers may take it for a black patch. Then for your oaths, I protest is out of fashion, I professe for a Justice of Peaces Wise, I vow too masculine, yfaith for a Chambermaid, Introth for a Landerer, As you hope to live, too like a Prayer; Never stir, would disadvantage a Lady many waies, besides visits; For the active wenches of the time, May they be damn'd eternally, and lose all their designs if it be not so; Upon my honour sounds well, which in a great Lady can never be forfeited if she be in love, for great women have their privilege of Nobility, and can never be forsworn like the Com∣mon people.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Is Perjury in women no breach of Laws?

SP.SPEAKER: 4 Lady.
SP.P: You have the Doctors opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: One touch, if you grow old, which I omit∣ted formerly, When time, which is the moath of beauty, creeps upon you, you must be sure to have so many leaves and curtaines before your windows, that you may shew your selves at more varions lights than the most cozening Mercer his faded and deceitfull Wares, for the youth of your white Satin will be then but pearle colour at the best, it may be but ash-colour, and therefore re∣fuse no advantage to give it gloss, according to the conclusion of a moderne Poet, which at this pre∣sent shall be mine.

Q.L: Wise Ladies must refuse no Art
For age will snow upon their heart:

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P:
You have done us a great honour, and Ladies you shall not deny me this favour to taste of a small banquet that waites upon you in the
next roome, shall I shew the way. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Sir William, Mr. Newman, Monsieur Galliard.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Me be content to have de litell patience, and be my trot, me tell you, vat me have seene a to day, de fine sport in devarle, me come into de great man to day, me make de reverence Ala∣mode, come ill faut, and he make me de estrange a Sir reverence de tird time, dat ever you saw.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: That was not civill.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Oh Monsieur, every man has not the activity of your feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: By my fat, 'tis very estrange a ding, dat dey will suffer a des men to be neere a de King, a de Queene, de Prince, or de Princesse, dey vil marra de understanding very mush.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Why Mounsieur that lyes at the o∣ther end.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Begar you shall excuse a me, for de Courtier Alamode, dere de vit lie in de foot, begar dere is nobodie can be viseman, dat does no make a de most excellent reverence, dat is most certaine, dat is the best ting in de hole varle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: I am cleare of his opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: But do you think Caesar Sir, or most of the Emperors or worthies of the world, studied the liberall science of the foot, or puissant toe?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: No, but begar dat make dem dye all un∣fortunate, for if dey had tinke of noting but de reverence, dey might ha live a great a while.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Excellent well argued, and very cleare in my understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P:
I confesse the wisedome of it Sir, but
for the wit do you thinke that lyes there?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Dat be de best vit can be possible, for your vit, vat is your vit? your vit is to breake a de jeast, vel, looke you now a me, me vil breake a de jeast, dat is like dat a me lor, dat is like dat of de Knight, dat is like dat of de Ientilman, ha, ha, ha! dere is now one, two, tre very good jeasts, by my trot dey are so very good jeast, dat make a me sicke wide laugh, and begar me vil make a de page, de lacquey, & all de foole in de court, breake a des very good jeast, very quickly, dat is a noting.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: To any purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: What doe you thinke of the grave Aldermen? they are wise, and yet they doe not trouble themselves much about legs.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Be my trot, me speake a to de King, and to de Queene, to give me a patten, dat none shall teach a de Aldermen to make a de reverence but my selfe, and me vil undertake dat vid in one 12 a mont, but den dey must doe nothing else, dey shall make a de reverence, vid de Aldermen in de paris, and dance a Coran, a Cereban, a Moun∣tague, and dat vil be very brave.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: VVhat faculties some men have?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: But what shall businesse do in the meane time Mounsieur?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Is not dis very great a businesse? may be∣gar, me vil undertake to de King and to de Queen to make a my Lor Mayre de Sheriff and de Al∣dermen very fine a mask.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: And to write it Mounsieur?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P:
Aw, de write? dat is noting alamode, your speesh two, tre, yard long, pshaw? give a me de quick a spirit, de fancie, de brave scene,
de varietie of de Antimasque, de nimble a foot, no matre de sence, begar it vole be de brave¦ting in de christian varle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: There is no question to be made.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: And be my trot if me have a noder patten for de counsell learned in the law, for to teach dem de reverence, dat vil be very great varke, but my diligence, and skill in dat matre, have no despaire, to effect in time dis great benefit, and dat vil make a de law flourish; and Englan a brave Englan, begar.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: I won't doubt your abilityes, but I feare the capacity of the Gentlemen you undertake.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: But what will you look for now, for your paines Mounsieur? that is considerable.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Begar me looke for very mush, for tis mush paine, and tis brave ting, beside me looke for a statur of de brasse, in de pallace yard, ven me goe out of dis varle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: You will deserve it as a rare patriot; but what manner of reverence would you have the grave lawyers to Imitate, you must consider their robes:

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Observe a me.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Such a reverence under your favour, would not become men of their gravity, one al∣wayes lookes for a Coranto after it, and provokes a man to whistle, or fing when he sees it, and makes one thinke still, what you would have a moneth, a little too much of the activity.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Begar you no understand de matre, vere is your breine? dere is noting in de varle like a dat motion, for de Ientillman, and for de Ientilvoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P:
Yes by your leave sir there is some∣thing
else that is as good for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: I vil tell you now, begar, here is a de kinsman dat is a me, and he live here very much time, before he come, dey vent in vid deir toes, and hold der cloke just a dere, and de hat so, fie, le diable! and now dey valk vid deir toes out for brave genty, you call dat a de splay foot, but me vonder dat de Lady no come, begar me no use to dis patience, and de vaite, pray tell you Madam dat me have autre busines vid de Lor, and de autre Lady have de use of my foot begar.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Oh Monsieur by no means.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: Let us prevaile.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Tis no good you hold a me, begar, me no stay two minute to save a your soule, dat is de re∣solution of de Cavalier de France.—Exit

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: Would any man beleeve there should be so much folly in this Cubit square?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Do you think he is a French Dancer? let that answer you, and wonder he has no more Caprichios. But these Ladies are very tedious, we must have this Lecture put down.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: They are more like to purchase Gresham Colledg, and enlarge it for publick Professors, you may live to see another University built, and only women commence Doctors.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: But now we talk of learned women, you have been acquainted with Mistris Voluble, has she the abilities the women talk of? they say she is a Fortune-teller.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P:
She is for more then Artificiall VVhite and Red, some think her guilty of the Black-Art, she has foretold so many strange things; she has had two Husbands, and prophesied long before, how,
and when they should give up the Ghost, if she be not a Witch she has the more wrong, for she is be∣leev'd a devillish cunning woman.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Possible!

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: There's no a Lady with child but con∣sults her Astrology, whether it shall be male or female; and the waiting women how long they shall keep their maidenheads, and who shall fa∣ther the first borne, the Master or the servingman; she is held a Sibill in the City, and tells oracu∣lously whether the Husband or the VVife shall die first, how, when, and where, and all this some∣time by observation of the hand, or forehead; she can see a maid through a maske, and is excel∣lent at stolne goods, for she can see a theefe through a millstone as well as a conjuring glasse; in brief, she is held prodigious at Divination, and most specially seldome failes in her Judgment of the two destinies, Matrimony, and Hanging, this I have heard Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Sr William Your Servant, Master Newman? that's he.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: Jeere him soundly.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: VVhat Gentlemen are these?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: He has betraid his ignorance already, he does not know us.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: VVhat, not the Major, and the Minor?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Not the Major, nor the Minor.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: Cede majori Sir, Cede majori.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: Parce minori Sir, Parce minori.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Here will be a fine conclusion from these premises, and they were worth considering.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: These two are wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: Are they your wits? Pray heaven you may not lose 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: If you love wit observe a little, and if I do not make you laugh, never laugh while you live.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: I thank you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: You shall here how I will jeere Newman, my Rivall now; such wit, wit of the last Edition: Let me have faire play, and these most ingenious friends of mine shall be judges.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: I think so, 'twill passe time till the La∣dies come.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Mr Newman, you are a pretty Scholler, pray what is wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: A thing you want.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: A very pretty Probleme.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: VVill you or these Gentlemen be bound to understand me?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, that's a clinch, to under∣stand me.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: A clinch?

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: I understand none.

SP.SPEAKER: Simpl.
SP.P: Oh sir, a palpable clinch; Ha, ha, ha, aske my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Is that your opinion?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Theres another clinch yfaith, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Pray sir, what is't a clock?

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: The mystery of this?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: VVhat is a clinch sir, do you know what 'tis?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P:
I neither know, nor care what 'tis, so I laugh, and sweare 'tis a clinch, that's disgrace and reproach enough to any man. With what ease can we cry up our own wit and anothers down, only by
saying that's a clinch. I think I ha jeerd him.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: Oh the waies to wit are much shortned in these latter times, 'tis a picant age.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: They have a gunpowder-plot to blow up sence; pray Gentlemen take truce with your spleenes, and the wisest of you three informe me what is wit; you have; no patience to heare me; or if you will not define it, speake something that is witty, and in fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: Ile tell you then:

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: You speak English to be understood, O base!

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: VVhat language is your wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: English, but elaborate, for example—now beat up your kettle drums.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jer.
SP.P: Sir, if my opticks faile not, I have read
Each mystick line within your brow, my Genius
Is much exalted at your gaudy Phisnomy;
Shal's to the house of mighty noise and surfets,
There tinctiour souls with bloud of purple grape?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: VVhat's all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Ha, ha, I thought you were ignorant.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: Give him the Paraphrase.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: All this is, he remembers perfectly he has seene you before.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: And desires you but to go to the Tavern, and drink a pint of wine; here's language!

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: Is't possible?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: VVhat a deale of Embroydery is spent upon I am glad to see you well; How long has this been a vulgar language? You would court a Mistris rarely in this Cabale.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: But how shall a man beget such high conceits?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Have you a desire to know Sir William? shall I tell him?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer
SP.P: If he will make it a secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Why, turne your selfe round as fast as you can, and the first things you speak, your head being dissie, will be these.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: What a beavy of Buffoons have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: VVe are at your mercy Gentlemen; but you that had a patience to expect so long, cannot want vertue to forgive, since we had no intent to make so great a trespasse; where's Monsieur Gal∣liard?

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: Madam, he's gone, something displeas'd you had no more regard to a Gentleman of his quality; his time was pretious, and some other Lords and Ladies expected him.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: His absence will admit of easie pardon, 'tis a most superstitious foole; what Gent. are these?

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: They are things were meant by nature, Madam, a cure for melancholly, we have had such sport and non-sence with 'em

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: VVe shall lose time upon 'em, please you, wee'l take a turne i'th Gallery.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Mistris Lucy be tender-hearted to these Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: They are only fit for your compassion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: They are worth your acquaintance, Ma∣ster Newman knows 'em; have not their wits a pretty edge?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Dismisse your Beagles I shall beat you all three else, and monstrously, indeed I shall; be rul'd, and keep your wits warme, I shall sling out like winter.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: I thank you sir and you be in earnest; I
protest Major, and Minor, the man's in wrath, away.
How now Iames.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.P: I am glad I ha found you sir, your mother's come to town, she rode behind me.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Not too loud, where is she? I would not have it known till she have other cloaths, and bet∣ter breeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.P: She's at your Lodging sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Mistris Ʋoluble, my mother's come by directions, mum, and make haste; sweet Mistris Lucy, I beseech you take it not unkindly if I de∣part.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: By no means noble sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: This is my man that has brought me newes out of the Country forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: None of your Tenants dead I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Some are Coppyholders, and I hope you wish me no harme, but I vow 'tis not my fault that I must take my leave so abruptly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: You have a cheerefull licence sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: As I hope to make new Leases, and sell a hundred Acres of wood this Terme, I am very sorry, but I will waite upon you in the Evening. Noble Mr. New.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Ha, ha, that's a clinch.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: I am your humble Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Another Clinch I protest. Ex. Sim:

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Now we have opportunity I preethee Mrs Voluble for my sake tell him his Fortune; I have been a stor to know your destiny.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: It will be a favour, it was in my ambition to desire it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: My Lady desires your presence in the gallery.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: I must observe her command, but you may satisfie the Gentleman in my absence, and Mr: Newman when you know how the starres have determined of you, make not me a more stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: I shal be onely fortunate to be yours.
Now Mistris Ʋoluble, if you be acquainted with my starres, and know what fortune they de∣cree me, I stand full prepared; what lines are in my forehead, you observe so?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: Pray let me see your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Freely command it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: Some that doe make a trade of fortune∣telling (which is beneath my practise) flatter mea for their base end of profit, Ile be plaine.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Truth loves no other habit, you pre∣pare me to give you the more faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: Tis very strange, but this is most pro∣pheticall, you are—

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: VVhat?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: In love.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: 'Tis very likely.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: It may not prove so lucky, love is a ma¦lanchoy businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: I thinke it be. Is this all you can tell by your art?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: You would know your destiny.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: VVhat please my starres and you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: Take this for oracle then, you will do something in a melancholy humour will enda¦ger your neck.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: My necke? shall I be hang'd? better the witch were burn'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: Fare you well Sir. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: A pox a your prognostick, she has put me
Into a sweat, and I doe more than halfe

Beleeve she is a witch, or worse, in a melan∣choly humour; must I doe something to endanger my necke? unth? I shall put my selfe into a des∣perate melancholy with thinking on't; I will be mercy, 'tis time to laugh and sing, thoughts doe not vex me to a new tune, ther's no way but to a Taverne, Ile seeke out company.

LG.L: Love by your leave a while, and lazy folly,
Sacke is the Antidote to melancholy.

DIV1.HEAD: Act. III. Scaena. I.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Simpleton, Mother (in riding cloathes) Mrs. Ʋoluble, fames.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: I Have obeyed you sonne, but I shall never sadge with these things you talke of.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Then y'are an asse, every childe can doe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: I, if I had been a Gentlewoman of a child, much might ha been done.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P:
Alas after a little time, you wil take pride every day of your selfe; I wonder this wench
comes not! what? your sonne has a care of you, and 'tis never too late to learne to be a Lady; this maide I commend to you, is a very rare dresser to a pinne, and will keepe your linnen with all variety of sweet bagges and powders, that can be imagined; and for your rich gownes, she will preserve 'em with the new fashion-sereclothes, and make them outlast Egyptian bodyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: But must my old Mistris be a Lady? that will be fine ifaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: The Taylour has taken measure for a Lady I am sure, and three or foure yards of Sat∣tin, more than will serve for a Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: Then she mun be kirstned, and call'd Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Peace and harken to my Landlady.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: Besides she has the rarest receits to de∣stroy moathes, and such a soveraigne medicine a∣gainst fleas, that your maides need never to squeak as if they were ravish'd, peeping into their smocks before they go to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: That will be fine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: The weneh I tell you on, knowes how to consume Cornes too, and for fidelity about your box of teeth, false haire, your glasse eye.—

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: My Mother has two eyes of her owne, but that one squints.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P:
Then for all manner of Caudles, Aleber∣ries, Possets, and preserves in all kinds, and should you lye in this maid will be the most diligent creature about warming of cloaths, and for brothes and gellies most excellent, and for all strengthners of nature; then if any of your wo∣men be to apt to conceive any thing that is ill,
she hath her drinkes of retention, and expulsi∣on—but Madam

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: She is no Lady yet.!

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: Sir I speake what I foresee, and there∣fore among our selves, Madam agen, this maid is very discreet, you will know what that meanes, not troublesom when your Ladiship would be private, nor suffer any else to trouble you, and beside she will never be in love, which is no small matter for a waiting woman; she is here already— Enter Nice. Mrs. Nice you are fortunate to be recom∣mended, to attend this, (but a Gentlewoman yet.).

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: She is too fine.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Hold your prating, and heare my Land∣lady, have not you clothes to come home?

SP.SPEAKER: Nice.
SP.P: I shall think my starres have been care∣full of me, if I may have the happinesse to shew my duty to so noble a Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: She calls me Lady too.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: They know what will become on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Oh that I could speake so gainely; I am but new come out of the Country, but if you please to be as good as your word, I will doe the best I can, to be thankfull, as they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: My mothers very raw, you must coddle her, you will have but a foule hand with her, doe you thinke she will ever come to any good? the truth is, I am asham'd on her, and therefore be not a knowne that she is my mother, till you ha' disciplin'd her, she must live very privately.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: How shall her name, person and estate be publish'd? do not you meane to have her a La∣dy?

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: By any meanes sir, and let me be one of her Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: I have it; do you observe the maid I commended to her? She is a Gentlewoman al∣waies bred among Ladies, and knows how to talk, and carry her self, before any Knight or Lord in the Court: What, if for the more expedite way to your mothers instructions this wench should take upon her sometime to be her Mistris, and in her name, before strangers, exercise some pride and courtship? 'tis a neerer way by example than precept to arive at any thing; and by observing her Fashion, Garbe, and Language, your mother may be sooner ripe for a Ladiship by at least two months, beside all the rules she may receive from us in private.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Admirable! My mother is a towardly old woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Old? you do not know how painting may transforme Age; and the wench is not so young as she seems; howsoever this will be only to stran∣gers, and you may with more reputation own her for your mother among Gallants, 'tis but saying she was married at twelve, and you pop'd into the world before thirteen.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: I will leave her to your tuition, and this Gentlewomans education.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Then 'tis thus Madam, come hither Nice.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Iames, thou shalt wait upon me to my Mistris when thou hast better cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.P: I have a new suite coming up from top to toe.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P:
Ile never live in the Country agen, such another clod was I when I came to London; mo∣ther
you must be dutifull, 'tis for your own good; but do you heare Landlady, have you spoke the powerfull word to my Mistris? Shall I have her from Newman?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: I have read his destiny, and if things hit with his credulous nature, he will make himself uncapable of her affection; you are the next in preferment, never feare it, and leave your mother to our method and government, we will both edi∣fie, and Ladifie her.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: With all my heart: buoy Lady mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: If please you wee'l withdraw; you must be secret Iames. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Manly (in Leisters habit) the two Ieerers meet him.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Ieer:
SP.P: What have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Ieer.
SP.P: The Ghost of Leister?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Ieer.
SP.L: Thus I have seen him painted,
'Tis some humorous Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Ieer.
SP.P: A proper fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: It is not dark enough; how they gape at me?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Ieer.
SP.P: Let's make sport with him, he shews admirably by twilight, he has not travelled far sure; such a shape would get money in Barthol∣mew Faire.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Ieer.
SP.P: Are you a high German sir?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Ieer.
SP.P: Yes, 'tis a Fencer; did you not heare of a Swisse that came over to be beaten at eight severall weapons?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Ieer.
SP.P:
By your favor sir, no, 'tis no high Ger∣man, those breeches are not worne in Switzer∣land,
there is something of the codpiece—

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Ieer.
SP.P: 'Tis not His Majesties Operatour for the Teeth, that hangs about Fleet-bridge.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Ieer.
SP.P: He's not so hansome.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Ieer.
SP.P: Were not you one of the brothers that guarded the Dyall at Bow Church, and us'd to put Cheapside in mind of their quarters?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Ieer.
SP.P: No, he wants a Pollaxe; do you think he came not off some Conduit?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Ieer.
SP.P: I am sure he came not off o'th' saltseller, He is a size too tall.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: These rogues will draw a Regiment of Prentices about me presently, and then shall I be apprehended for some sea monster, and thrown into the Thames at the next Staires, to shew their worships how well I can swim—have you any thing to say to me?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: 'Tis English that he speaks, he is one of us.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: I am one that will venture to beat you both in the same language, if you leave me not the sooner.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: 'Tis some that skulkes in this disguise for debt; we'l say we are Officers, and pretend to arrest him.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Nay then have at you bandogs—
SP.STAGE: Enter Newman, and Gentlemen, (their swords drawn.)
SP.P: A reskue?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Ieer.
SP.P: Hold.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Down with the Bayliffes, arrest a Gentle∣man in the Kings high way— Ex. Manly

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: So, so, he is escap'd. Ex. Gent.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P:
You cursed tadpoles, cannot a Gentle∣man
walk i'th' streets, but such Tenterhookes must catch him by the cloak?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Ieer.
SP.P: Noble Master Newman, we are your servants; do not you know us? we are no offi∣cers.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.L: Ha? If my opticks erre not, I have read
Each mystick line within your brows,
Ye shall both—

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Ieer.
SP.P: Have our skins cut into measures.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: To the Taverne with me.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: With all our hearts.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: We will be drunke together.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: You shall command us..

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: At my new Taverne where the wine shal flow as at a Coronation; fifty Fiddles, and a noise of Trumpets come along with me; you two shall send your tickets out for wenches.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Ieer.
SP.P: Of all complexions, and degrees, from the Madam Alamode, to the humble Wastco∣teere. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: I beseech you Mrs Lucy make not me the Author, I affect Mr Newman, but this I receiv'd from good intelligence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: I am miserable; I did not think his nature could degenerate into so wild a change, it is some witchcraft, I must grieve for him though I dare not shew it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fo.
SP.P: Ther is a report, I would be loath you should name me in't, but they confidently say; I dare not justifie upon my knowledge, that he has kild—

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Good heaven defend; then I am more un∣done.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Nay, these are the fruits of wine and sur∣fets; I did not see him bleed, but I heard it from a man of quality, and one that had been Colle∣ctor in the Parish, who told me for certaine that Mr Newman did kill him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Whom? my afflicted heart.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: It was an Ossicer that was slaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: The more unpardonable.—VVhere?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: In the Parish of Alhallowes Barking, the Bell man never dawnd since, comming drunk out of a Taverne at twelve—he made no more adoe—there was not such another dog within the VVals; it waited upon the foresaid Bell-man a nights in His Majesties service, to waken the Pa∣rish, and all day was hir'd out by a Blind-man, that beg'd, with a Bell about his neck.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Is that all the murder he has committed?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: All? you do not consider the blind Begger that's undon by't, or who shall carry the Lanthorne at midnight, to light Gentlemen to the best Ale, and a Bawdy-house; but for my part Ile be no evidence, if the City will suffer such an in∣justice within their VValls I can be silent, and think.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: VVould this were all the danger, but I seare since he took up this rudeness and strange carriage he may deserve more sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: I love not to meddle in other mens affairs, but I know something.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: I prethee tell me all.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P:
The Taverne he frequents he has made his Pheater at his own charge to act intempe∣rance; o're the great Roome be uses to be drunk in, they say, he has built a heaven, a Players hea∣ven,
and thence a Throne's let down, in which, well heated, successively they are drawn up to the clouds to drink their Mistris health, while the mad mortals adore their God of Grape, and gaping look like earth that's chap'd with heat, although before within three minutes they were drench'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Dost know that place?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: You shall excuse me, I know nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Prethee be not so cautious, I am his friend, and pity him; if for my sake thou woo't but find him out, and tell him I desire to change but a few words, trust me, I may amply requite this service.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: You must then keep secret what I un∣dertake, Ile do't. Be cautious to whom you speake, we must be circumspect. I will go off invisible. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Monsieur Galliard, my Lady expects you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Begar me no like a dat reverence, me vil change a dat:

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: 'Tis the French fashion as you taught Me Monsieur.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Ouy, tis de French fashion, but de French fashion is alwaies to change, and dis reverence displease a me very mush, because you go back, back vid your buttock, as if some vod take you by dat, to vat me vil give a no name.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: Monsieur Galliard my Ladie will be here presentlie.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Sweet Mrs Lucie.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P:
Dat de reverence is no good of de man, me must change dat too; by me trot me doubt dat dis great business vil almost break a my braine,
dis great varke, and before a maske of de King and de Queene, me can eate a no meate, no drinke, no sleepe, and me growe so very a leane, vid de contemplation, a so much, by my trot de privy counsell is no so much troubled as me be vid dis, oh, le Diable! deirs is noting, dey sit all the vile dey doe deir busines, me bissey bo'te head, and de foot cap a pie, in de french tune, and dat is great matre begar.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: You esteeme it highly Mounsieur.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Me tell you, and me tell you no tale, tis great matre to make a de Lor, to make a de Lady, to make a de Gentleman, to make a de Gentil∣voman, and de autre man to dance, and to make a de good reverence, for begar dat vil make a de King, de great kin in de varle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: How can that be Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Me tell you, ven dey are so bissey, to learne a de dance, dey vil never tinke of de Re∣bellion, and den de reverence is obedience to Monarchy, and begar obedience is ale de ting in de varke.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: I'le sweare your state affaires ly in your foot, and you are wifer there, than some heads are, and may be a president for after ages; but what musick would you governe the people by?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Begar by de best french fidles can be got?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: What thinke you of an Irish harpe, a state organ, or a pastionate voyce to a lovers lute?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P:
Des dull tings make a de men melancho∣lique, and den dey tinke on de Devill, and de
treason, and do any ting dat is no good, but be∣gar des french fidles doe fidle all deis tings out of deir head, vid such a Jearke, as ma foy make a dem so phantasticall, and make a dem as good subject, as any is in de France begar.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I must waite upon my Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: She will be here immmediately.—
She is not right yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Here be one of my coliers, Mounsieur Sim∣platon, say you no dat de french fidle make a de brave government in de varle?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: I say any thing becomes a Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Observe you dat? he have been but two are mont and he say any thing, dat is very brave? he have de grand understanding in de foot; tell a me, ven you heare a de little fidell, vat is your tinke? is your head no free from de treason, and plot of de rebell, as your leg? begar you no stand upon de ground for Joy of de Coran, de Cerebran, de Marquiss, de Mountague, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: My Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Me be your humble servant Madam, and stay one two tre houre.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: I am now ready for you Mounsieur, come Lucy the practise of the last he taught us.

DIV1.STAGE: Lady and Lucy dance, Mounsieur singing, and correcting them in tune.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: The Gentleman you expect Sir VVilliam is come.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Madam prepare your selfe for mirth, 'twill be a sight beyond the pageants.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Wee'l not be seen at first, Lucy with∣draw.— Exit Lady and Lucy.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: What meanes this flourish? have you a play in hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.L: To bid your excellence welcome to this lodging.
Fore Jove he lookes prodigiously, vouchsafe
Us th' honor of your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Vat Antick be dis?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: One of the supporters of the Brewers Armes.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, does he take upon him to be a Prince too, and will he speake?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: These Ladyes have ambition to kisse your hand, and have a great desire to know, how fares the campe at Tilbury, and please your Ex∣cellencie.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: 'Tis one of Arthurs Knights of the round Table.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: VVith his circular sippets; would you thinke that a pigmy poison'd should swell thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: I am betraid, there's no retreat with honour, I must be confident.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
