SP.P: Laugh and Jeere him hansomely.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Oh that the Major, and the Minor had been here now, they would teeze him ifaith, Mounsieur, aske that Maypole and he can dance.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Plait il Mounsieur? a la Galiard, de Goran, la Princesse, le Buckingham, heigh!

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P:
Put up your rosin, and your cats∣guts
presently and be gon, or I shall finde a grave for you in the pocket of my sleeve, and this shal be your winding sheet.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Me no play dat lesson, pocket de sleeve, dat is no tune de France, poket, le grand pock:— (Manly offers to strike him) pardonne moy Mounsieur: me put up my fidell and be gon, adieu Madam, Serviteur gentilhomes; pocket de sleeve? Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: But I must not seeme angry, Lady, my businesse is to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Businesse to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: I am bold to present a sute to you, I confesse it was not made by a French Tailor, I can make a leg and kisse my hand too after the fashion of my cloaths, this serv'd in those honest dayes, when Knights were Gentlemen, and pro∣per men tooke the walls of dwarfes; here's a belly peece, that lookes like armour, with what come∣linesse may a man unbutton his dublet, when he seemes to take the wall to make urine? your sleeve so neere your nose, with a handkerchiefe, which I take out thus with a grace, after Emuncti∣on, I put up agen, with the corianders hanging out, Geometricall breeches in severall slises, in which a man is not asham'd of his thighes, nor hides his bow leggs, which at the bottome sur∣rounded with points make him look like a rough∣sooted Pigeon, these things were worne when men of honor flourish'd, that tam'd the wealth of Spaine, set up the States, help'd the French King, and brought Rebellion to reason Gentle∣men.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: So they doe now.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Peace pepper corne; and all this at lesse charge than a masque comes to now, with the rare and new invention of hobbiehorses; which of our two habits (be you Lady, but the indifferent Judge, and squint not,) is the more grave and manly, his leane upper chinne, or this goodly promontory? my Trunkes with a round walke pav'd with gold and silver, or your trouses, cut close to your dock, and drawne on with a screw? in which if you venture but halfe a crowne, lookes like a poltisse, or a swelling in the groine; your habit is phantasticall as the time, you squirt into your dublet, which you weare so carelesse as you had not button'd it since you came from a baw∣dy house, where men of this garbe, coming from the stewes, march with that gravity as they came from a conventicle, so soherly they would carry it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: I see whoring was equall in all times, onely the carrying of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Why that's all?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: But surely I doe wonder, how my Grandfather could kisse my Grandmother, or embrace in that strange apparell.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: They made a shift Knight, or else your wise worship had not been here; but that I want so much beard, I could shew how your Grandfa∣ther stroak'd his three or foure handfull of haire, to the terrour no doubt of the standers by, and could stab I warrant you, with his two handed beard then, as well as you with your dagger beard now. It was never a good time since these cloaths went out of fashion; oh, those honourable dayes and persons!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Is't possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: As how?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: I pray inlarge your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: To have seene but a St. Georges feast then.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Why, what difference sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: When they were install'd, to see the twenty mile to Windsor strow'd with blew∣coates, feathers and cognizances, as they do coun∣try townes with boughes, and flowers for Princes Entries, and not to go privately in a coach, with a page and a barber to cut off charges.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: How doe you like this Gentleman, Is't not a pretty humour?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Then you should have the best knight of the Countrey, with the ragged staffe on their sleeves.

LG.L: The Beare, the Boare, and Talbot with his tuskish white,
Oh so sore that he would bite,
The Talbot with his Tuskish white
Soudledum Soudledum;
The Talbot with his Tuskish white Soudledum, bell.
The Talbott with his Tuskish white
Oh so sore that he would bite
Orebecke soudledum, sing orum bell.

SP.P: Every Knight had his hundreds, and these would take up all the Tavernes in the Towne, be druoke to the honour of their Lords, and rather than not pay their reckoning, pawne their chains, though they pawn'd something for them the night before, and such merry catches then, as

LG.L: The Hart loves the high wood,
The Hare loves the hill,
The Knight lov'd his bright sword,
And the Lady lov'd her will.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: So the Ladies do still.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: It may be so, but for your Knights bright Sword 'tis at pawn, or at home in his Armory; then we had, God blesse the Duke of Norfolke, there was a jeast, and another Song.

LG.L: The great Choe bent,
The little Choe bent,
Sir Piercy leigh under the line;
God blesse the good Earle of Shrewsbury
For he's a good friend of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: He's very confident.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Alas, he is compel'd to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: How do you like this Mrs Lucy, is he not a pretty ill-favour'd Gentleman in this habit?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: He sings rarely.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: No question he can dance too, in that disguise he lookes like famous Cardell the dancing. Master in Queen Elizabeths time, I have seen his Picture.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: And he with your Worships favour, was held a wise man, and for his gravity he might have been Treasurer, he went with that setled and solid Pian-piano.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P:
And when he danc'd a measure, you should have had him with his Rapier, short Cloak,
his black Cap, and his white Feather, his single and double, both backward and forward, with that excellencie—

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: And now he must be in Cuerpo, or like a fellow on the ropes, or a Tumbler when he shoots his body through a hoop; there was musick then, and a Heaven and Earth, beyond your braules, or your Mountague, with a la, la, la, like a Bachana∣lian dancing the Spanish Morisce, with knackers at his fingers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: It must needs be a rare sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: He plaid to himself on a grave Lute, or a modest Citterne, with a politick quill, far beyond your Geofrey fiddle, or your French kit, that looks like a broken fagot stick, at the biggest, and sounds as if it had got the French disease, when it snivels out a Coranto, or so hoarse with a cold, as if some great base Fiddle had filenc'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: What misery is it, the Monsieur is gone now? here had been a French Duell.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: But had you seen my Lord Loftie dance the Galliard, with such capers, such half capers, such turns o'th toe, and above ground, you would have sworn 'em sound for nine Generations, and for Lavaltoes, La, la, la, &c. and then the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: How did he use her?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: With wonderfull skill, he put his right arme about her, and took her lest hand in his, and then he did so touze her with his right thigh and legg, and list her up so high, and so fast, and so round—

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: As what I pray, be curteous.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P:
Marry as soon as he had ended his dance she would lye down as dead as a swing'd chicken,
with the head under the wing, so dissie was she, and so out of breath; and all these wonders were extant Knight when this old Cap was new.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: Is not this very fine sport Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Sir, y'are welcome; pray excuse me, if being prepar'd for some folly, your garbe and per∣son seem'd at first ridiculous; you have chang'd my opinion, and there wants but such a noble lea∣der to reduce, and make this habit fashionable; it shews a proper man, and if I were worthy to ad∣vise, or could lay an obligation upon you, I should take it for an honour if you would often visit me in these ornaments, I like 'em infinitely, and the Wearer shall be ever welcome; please you wee'l walk and talk a turn in the Gallery.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: You too much grace me Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.L: How's this?
I have wound my self into a pretty business,
She neglects me.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: In my judgment 'tis an indifferent pret∣ty fellow, but that his cloaths are out of fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: They are most becomming; I do not like your new phantasticall shapes, that transforme a man from his masculine aspect; you appear to me like a Jackanaps; there's a waste, and a Long lane cut close to your hanches. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P:
Hum! she takes after the old one, I will try and shift my self, if the mother be taken with the habit in Qu. Elizabeths daies, why may not the daughter affect that in K. Jameses, and so the humor run in a bloud? I am resolv'd; she loves sing∣ing too, I am furnish' with Ballads, o'my consci∣ence
this will do't; Ile fit her with a fashion, and about it presently. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: They are here agen, and laugh at me: How familiar the Turtles are?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Wee'l taste some aire i'th' garden, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: So, so, if I did love this widow for her self, what a case were I in? but I must not sit down thus, and something must be thought on for my honour. Exeunt.

DIV1.HEAD: Act. IIII. Scaene I.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Mistris Voluble, and Nice, (having a Jewell.)

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: SO, so, thou dost carry it excellently, it spreads like a Proclamation, what a rich widdow lies at my house, her wealth, and wit, must be exercis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: She must not appeare to be herself yet but in private, and the Chiause her Son has be∣stow'd this Jewell upon me for expedition, for he dares not yet acknowledge her; she wonders at her¦self now she is painted, & sweares in her conscience she looks by her glass like one of foure and twenty, and simpers, and licks her leatherne lips as she had eaten Marmalade.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Sir William has heard of her, and (upon some affront, as I conjecture receiv'd from my Lady) has writ to me, and articled already to dispose her affections, I expect him every minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: He will discover us.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: He shall never see thee act her part.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: Do you thinke he can affect her?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: Courtiers do not marry into the City for love, and this Farmers wife has wealth enough to Enter Simpleton, and James, (with his cloaths.) buy a Ladiship; here's the gull, away and be dili∣gent. Exit Nice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: They'l fit you as well as my self for whom they were made in the Countrey.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: How now sir, preparing for a race?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Is no body else with you? Do not en∣quire what stratagem is in hand, there be more waies to catch a Mistresses heart; how does my mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: She is pretty apt for one of her yeares: I can tell you news, there is a Knight about her already.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: She shall have him.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Not with your favour if a greater person Interpose, I have so much care of her honour, now she is my charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: Mistris Voluble, here's a Footman, lac'd all over, enquires for you, he serves a French Lord, he saies he must needs speak with you, he has a letter. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: What if this Lord come hither for the same purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P:
Tis too much happinesse; Ile not be
seen thus, nor let my Mother appeare in her roughcast, use the Footman kindly, if his mes∣sage concerne us, away— Exit Ʋol.
And will this Fashion become me, dost thinke? I prethee tell me some old stories in to'ther raigne, thou canst talke and make me ready too.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: Ah sir, I knew a time, when two and twen∣yeares was but a merry Christmas, nothing but Ambassadors, Masques, Playes, Entertainements, Hawking, Hunting, Winter and Summer, New-Market and Roiston mourne now, ha! had you seen the Court fox'd upon Gouries night, and the Gunpouder treason began then; oh we had rare sport, and then every body was knighted, they hardly lest a Gentleman in those dayes; and afterward they got a tricke of making Lords.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: For what?

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: I know not that, but they hardly left a Knight, man, woman, and childe were made right honourable.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Right honourable, right worshipfull, and well beloved, I have heard that in the Coun∣try.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: But the fashion of welbeloved is left off, for we doe not now love one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: But had you no misfortunes?

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: Faith Sir, a rainy day was the worst, and that had but made the ground more soluble the next day for hunting.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: No complaints James?

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P:
Oh yes sir! I hard a Gentleman complaine mightily that he had lost the highest flying tassell gentle, that ever was seene, another that he had
prick'd his grey Nag, that was an excellent buck∣hunter; a third, that he had fretish'd his best hound, Beauty, and that Lilly was kill'd at a Bay a stag-hunting, it had almost cost the Genleman his life.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: And what else James?

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: By my troth sir, a Gentleman waiter, that shall be namelesse, removing a pasty of Venison, spilt it all, on a new satten doublet, and spoiled it utterly, there was such laughing, but his Master being gracious gave him a sute for his doublet, I thinke it was a Knight; but the Knight market is risen now.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: I and the Lord Market too, James.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: And please your worship, they say, the Herald would not make a Gentleman now, under ten pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Oh yes, they'l take reason to my knowledge, and give the prettiest phantasticall armes, I have all the colours of the Rainebow in my new coate, every foole may be a Gentleman of three generations now.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: I can derive my selfe knave three de∣scents under your ancesters.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Then thy children may write them∣selves knaves of blood, take that upon my Heral∣dry; but had not you brave songs then James?

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P:
In those dayes was the quintessence of ballads, you went to schoole with 'em, I remem∣ber and learn'd no other bookes, I shall never for∣get the Lord of Lornes sonne in Scotland and the false steward, to the tune of greene sleeves, those were the dayes indeed, oh there was then such a company for dancing singing and fooling, I doe
not meane the wits, for sooling is another thing cleare from it; It does so bravely in company, when there is a great many that care not for wit, and pleases better than all the wit in the world; and then there was such brave jeasts, at the death of a Stag, and Buck; to throw blood up and downe, upon folkes faces; the very Footn en and Pages understood those Jeasts then; there was a time; and the Landerers were as well Employed in a progresse then as now, and the Surgeons got as much by 'em too; oh, I shall never forget those times.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: So, so, how doe I looke in this transfor∣mation? will any body know me dost thinke? Mistris Lucy, shall have the first sight of my shape; some body is gone into the dining roome, let us out at the backe doore James. Exeunt.

DIV1.STAGE: (Enter Nice. (dressing the Mother, painted) (at another Doore) Mrs. Ʋoluble.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: 'Tis well done Nice to be carefull about your Mistris.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: I am giving her some instructions about dressing, and was saying, she must not goe above once to court in black, it would be very scanda∣lous without intermixing colours, in her petti∣cote, sleeves, and stomacher, and the colours now in fashion are blew, pincke, and incarnadine, yel∣low is much worne too.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: But 'tis very materiall, what lace you wil choose, as silver and gold for blew, (Tha's a court maxime) and plaine silver for incarnadine, single or mixt will serve for pincke colour.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: I shall never remember all this.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: It is your Gentlewomans duty to remem∣ber.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: Let me alone Madam. When you will keepe house, a long handkercheife, or a round one with a quaife tied under your chin, and a lit∣tle haire curl'd, with a black taffa ta hood, or white sarfenet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: When you pretend to have a cold, you must shew no haire, but weare a forehead cloth, with a pinner over that, these cloathes are much worne by old Ladyes, with which they binde downe a peece of sea recloth upon their forehead, to keepe wrinckles in obedience. How is her haire?

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: That little that she has is crazie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: She has enough to curle, and you have the discretion to know what proportion is to be lest out, according to the latitude of her face; and to be curl'd with pinnes and orrice pouder, which will neither hurt nor breake it, and then in the Morning to let the combe passe through it once, and open it, between a curle and a freeze, and draw up some of the curles with a bodkin within the other haire.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: My haire will never indure all this.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: You must endure more, if you meane to be a Lady of fashion, and attractive; where be the pendants?

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: Must she not weare a Feather?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: Not without a diamond bodkin; have you no Jewels?

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Yes, In the knot of my handker∣chiefe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: Oh fie, you must buy a Cabinet. What's here? a Toad stone, two Turkies, sixe thumb∣rings, three Aldermens seales, five Gemmals, and foure Deaths-heads; these are Alehouse orna∣ments—Yet these Diamonds are tollerable, and these Pearles will make a half Chaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: Would she were hangd in the fellow, con∣dition we had the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: They must be changd, but Nice may weare these til you get new, they will serve to practice in. (Knock within.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: There's a Coach at doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Ile pawne my ability the French Lord, 'tis about the time I gave directions to his Foot∣man; for his entertainment, you must take upon you the rich widdow, and be you carefull to ob∣serve Mrs Nices Language, garbe, and behaviour, to men of his quality; your Rings and Jewels up∣on her will credit the cause, and person he comes to visit, which is your self, but under a vaile. Ile prepare his Lordship. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: This is all for your instruction; these rings fit me excellent well, and hereaster you may take pride upon you by my example.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: I hope I shall learne in time; but I shall be more than a Lady if I marry with a Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: Alas, I am but the Lady in the Play.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: Now you put me in mind, I have seen pret∣ty harlotry Ladies in a Country Play, so proud, and so knavish, one would have sworn they had been women indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P:
Hee's here, you must be modest, and ob∣serve your distance now; Is this the Lord? He
looks like an over-grown Monkey.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: What pretty foolish things some of these young Lords are?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Your Lordship is bountifull; that is she whom fame hath delivered to you; your honour may advance.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Begar dis rish viddow looke young as my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol
SP.P: If my eyes be not in a mist this is the French Dancer.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Vat is your name?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: He means to catechise her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: I shall be happy if your Lordship please to own me by the title of your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: You must learne to complement thus—'Tis Galliard sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: She kisse very vel begar, she have de Ala∣mode touch of de lip ma foy; can you dance Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: I am now confirm'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: Will he kisse me too?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Vat is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: A Gentlewoman that attends me for the present.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Dat is a de reverence for de divel, she look like a de wihch Madam, but me tell you Ma∣dam, for me love you very mush in the little time, as any man in de varle; me be French Lor, and me have lodging in de autre street, Duke de Me∣morency my kinsman, and two tre hundred great Lors have lose deir head in France begar for no matre, and me flye to Englan to save a me neck by me trot.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: Were you guilty of any treason?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal
SP.P: No more begar than your little self.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: What is your estate?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Begar very grand estate in Orleance, me have two tre Lettre from de Cardinall, and he write a me, dat de King send for me to kiss his hand: Now as me vas in de resolution to take a de ship for France, me heare of you Madam in de Strand, and me very glad to marry you before me go presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: Your Lordship is very briefe, but I find not my self enclin'd to crosse the Seas.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: The Sea, mary shield, Ile not see the salt water for any Lord in Christendome, I, Ile rather be no Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: Who, how now insolence, how dare you interpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Will you be ridiculous, and betray your self now?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Begar you have de Gypsey complexion, and looke like de sign of-de Robin Hood and maid a Marian.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: Robin Hood in thy face, does he maid a Marian me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: She is not worth your Lordships passion, I shall teach you better manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Begar you shall have mush need of dat.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: My Lord, you did aske me if I could dance.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: The wench has found him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Dere is noting in de varle for de Lady, like a de understanding in de foot.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: I cannot praise my own ability, but I ad∣mire the excellency of other Ladies, and should be fortunate to meet with some Master in thafa∣culty, that would Instruct, and exercise me in private.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Me love you de bettre for da, begar no body exercise you in private but my self, me teach you Alamode de Court dance, hold up your litel fingre you command a my foot.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: Your Lordship is too humble, it is an office would become one that is mercenary; I af∣fect dancing infinitely, oh that we had but some musick here; la, la, ra. (She sings, Gal. draws out his Fiddle.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: is comming out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: What's that a bedstaffe?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: It is a French pocket-pistoll.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: Will he shoot it oft here? I could never indure a gun. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal
SP.P: Forboon, brave, ah, dat is like a de Prin∣cess, Allez.

SP.SPEAKER: N
SP.P: You shall not be so publick in your graces to me; conceale your Fiddle tillsome private op∣porunity.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Me understand.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: How does your Lordship like her? You have her in an excellent humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Kisse a me madam—hah? 'tis heaven? de Poet talke of de Nectar, begar here is it; me never drink devine blanke or de Claret, so me have but two tre drop divine from your lip—Metresse speake a for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: The foole is extasied; in his worst conditi∣on he will serve for a husband; how he dances in a Net?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: He has money, and a Trade, he will serve wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: If me get dis rish widdow, me cozen 'em both begar.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: Do you think he loves me indeed. Ex. Vol.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: You no tinke madam dat me be so hot in love, and do burne, dat my reine a do melt, as me vere in de oven, me need a go into de river pre∣santly to coole and vater my heart, vere is de Mi∣stresse de la Maison? Gone? dat is vel, dere is no honor like a dat, as you take a de litel aire in my Coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: I have not been abroad to day, but I dare trust my self with your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Oh Madam, a vostre service, now if me get a de Priest all is perfect.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: Be all these Trunkes hers?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: We ha not stowage enough for half, she is infinitely rich.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: Hast thou prepar'd her?

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: I find her very apt, 'tis her only ambition to be a Lady, a French Lord has her in chase, but I have delivered your character, and what privi∣ledge she may have by charter of her Knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: I long to see her, is she handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: What she wants in beauty and breeding, she has in estate Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: That, that's enough, I can have beauty in other places, and will exceed what I conditi∣on'd for, if I prosper. I will have this Widdow in spight.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: How Sir William?

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: To spight the Lady Beaufield, and her Magog that affronted me; I would lose no opor∣tunity, a widdow must be taken in the pick; say I am come and commend me to the heavens, Ile make all good.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: To the heavens? will you dye before her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Will.
SP.P: For that we must take our chance; thou shalt be sure of a good lease for thy life, and desti∣ny agree upon us afterward.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Shall I direct you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Wil.
SP.P: Sha't be my evening, and my morning star. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: You too much afflict your self Mistris Lu∣cy, 'tis but some humour he put on to try the strength of your affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: He is lost; not for my sake, but for his own I pitty him, and I am confident, if I were so hap∣py to speak with him agen, I should prevaile to win him to his first and noble temper; my end being so just, I could dispence with modesty to find him out, and perfect the act of charity.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: You have imployd Formoll, from whom you may expect to heare such an account, as may dry up your sorrows.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: I see Sir you preserve your confidence.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: I dare be just in your commands, and in a service you but smile upon, despise the censure of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Saw you not the Knight since?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: The sweet hopes that he swallow'd, to prepare me a ridiculous object to you Madam, was gall upon his stomack, when he found you had mercy on my confidence; he dares not converse with so unlick'd a beare, as this shape must present Enter Simpleton, and James. his criticall eye sight. Whats here? one sent to affront me?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.

LG.L: When Robin came to Nottingham dery, dery down,
His dinner all for to dine:
There met him fifteen olly Foresters,
Were drinking Ale, and Wine, hey down.

SP.P: Madam your most humble servant; there be other men, and manners, and garbes as fashionable in the eyes of discreet Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Have we got Adam Bell, and Clim o'th Clough?

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: We be three, good Mr William of Cloudesly.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: 'Tis so.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: And how, and how shew matters Mistris Lucy? every mans Cap is not made of the same matter.

L.HI: Have you felt the wooll of Beaver?
—Have you smelt of the bud of the Rose?
—Or have tasted the bag of the Bee?

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Sir, this is most uncivill, and your rash∣nesse, beside the forfeit of your own discretion, will lay an imputation to wound my fame; with∣in my presence, and beneath my roofe, which should protect all strangers, to affront a Gentle∣man that visits me—

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: How's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Be bold sir, and presume you have my favour, you never appear'd handsome till this minute; beare up, your mirth becomes you rare∣ly.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Dos't isaith?

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: What does my mother meane?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Spit o' thy hand, and clap me oth' shoulder Iames, the widow her selfe is in love with me.

LG.L: She cast an eye on little Musgrave
As bright as the summers sunne.

SP.P: I may turne o're the Daughtet to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: I would I had her in an Embroiderd clout.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Sure my Lady is but in jeast.

LG.L: Shew me said he whose men ye be
That hunt so boldly here,
That without my consent do chase
And kill my follow Deere.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: His follow Deere?

LG.L: Ere thus I will out braved be
One of us two shall dye,
I know thee well an Earle thou art,
Lord Percy, so am I.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: Thou Douglas?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P:
This Lady has but fool'd me all this while; make much of your new Antick Madam, I can shift into my selfe agen, and if that thing were worth my anger, or my envy, beate him;
you have a pretty humour, cherish it, and that William of the Wispe, till I visit you agen.— Exit

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: The Gentleman is jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: I protest Madam if it had hot been not your sake, and that it had been pitty to have spilt any blood, in your Dining roome, I would ha done something

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: In his breeches.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: But I shall report your noblenesse a∣broad.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Doe not play the foole to much, I am out of the humour to laugh at you; he cannot leave me thus.— Exit Beau.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: This was no tricke to catch the old one.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: How came you into this habit Simpleton?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: By reading Ovids Metamorphosis, and to shew the variety of my wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Let me entreat you hold your feet toge∣ther,—now you put me mind of a Smiths bel∣lowes, your body is not all of a peece sure, but severall limbes thrust into severall pudding bags, you would shew terrible to the crowes in a wheat field, you are no living creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Perswade me to that, am I not sensible?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: He that does that cure upon you, will de∣serve a chronicle; so desiring you would take home your flaile there, for here is like to be no thrashing worke, I commit you to the Barne, where like another Orpheus, you will draw the horse, and sheepe, to the melody of your voyce, and ravish all the Cowes in the Countrey, to heare you sing Packingtons pound.— Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: She has made a coxcombe on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P:
Hum? I wo'not out o'the pit for all this, I
have another devise, and thou shalt assist me, if that faile, I'le dye a bachelor, and make thee my heire.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: I shall but pray for your death sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.L: Back agen, back agen quoth the Pindar,
The wrong way have you go, &c.

DIV1.STAGE: A Table, Stooles, Bottles of wine, and Glasses, set out by two Drawers.—then Enter Newman, the two Jeerers, Wenches, Musitians.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: So, so, I'le dance no more, a song, lets have a song now.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Wen.
SP.P: Take heed of the old ballads, ecclip∣ed, Like Hermit poore, eyes hide my love, or Panae in the brazen Tower.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Wen.
SP.P: Or the lamentable complaint of Ariad∣ne, and Theseus, and the more lamentable for being so long.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Doe you heare Madam vertue, Lady modesty cannot you play your part?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Je.
SP.P: Not upon the violin.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Je.
SP.P: They are both for the Gambo.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: You shall play the part of my Mistris, you must be witty then, and extreame coy and scurvy, in your answers; go behind that hanging, I will suppose it your chamber; now Boy the Song I made to the window, while I mustle my selfe with the fidlers, to bid my Mistrisse good morrow in the street, observe the conjuration.

LG.L: I conjure thee, I conjure thee, by thy skin that is so faire,
Thy dainty curled haire,
And thy favour and thy grace,
With the patches on thy face,
And thy hand that doth invite
The cold, dullest appetite,
—Appeare appeare,
Ʋpon these termes I doe invite thee,
And if thou com'st I will delight thee.
If not so, I doe not care,
Though thy breasts be ne're so bare,
Roses rich, with shooe that's white,
Or thy Venus best delight,
If not touch thy softer skin
What care I for thee a pin,
Appeare appeare.
For to heare, and not to see
Is a dull flat history,
And to see and not to touch
If you thinke the last too much,
Know all woman's but one ioy
If we men not them enjoy,
Appeare appeare.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: She's not awake, play a ratling tune that may startle her; where's this whore? ha!—

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jer.
SP.P: She's gone.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jer.
SP.P: Vanish'd? so he might have sung a∣way his lungs.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: It may be, she is retir'd, for you know what Lady; come let us drinke.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Wench.
SP.P:
Was your Muse at all this expence
to the fidles? do you write to no other company sir?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Till they have my liveries; Ile maintaine 'em in songs, wind up your voyce agen▪

LG.L: Thine eyes to me like sunnes appeare
Or brighter starres their light;
Which makes it summer all the yeare,
Or else a day of night:
But truely I doe thinke they are
But eyes, and neither sunne nor starre.
Thy brow is as the milky way,
Whereon the gods might trace:
Thy lips Ambrosia I dare say
Or Nectar of thy face:
But to speake truely I doe vowe
They are but womens lips and browe.
Thy checke it is a mingled bath
Of Lillyes and of Roses;
But here there's no man power hath
To gather loves fresh posies:
Beleeve it here the flowers that bud
Are but a womans flesh and blood.
Thy nose a promontory faire,
Thy necke a necke of land;
At natures gifts that are so rare
All men amaz'd doe stand:
But to the cleerer judgement those
Are but a womans necke and nose.
For foure lines in passion I can dye
As is the lovers guise,
And dabble too in Poetry
Whilst love possest, then wise
As greatest States-men, or as those
That know love best, yet live in Prose.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: The pure spirit of Sack in't.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: The wits Elixar.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: No jeering Gentlemen, I shall grow loud and break the peace.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Wen.
SP.P: These Gentlemen are for nothing but song and drink, I see no market all this while; Ile get me hence too; if please you, Ile see if I can find out my sister. Ex. 2 Jeer.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: There's but one stoole in the counting house, and Lady you shall stay till she returne; Gentlemen there's no life in you; I cannot do this roring and whoring handsomely; little thinks Lucy what Comrades I have got.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Wen.
SP.P: I have a pretious confidence in you Gen∣tlemen, to trust my single modesty amongst so many.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: VVhat would you give to be ravish'd now? thou hast an excellent complexion for't.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Wen.
SP.P: Ravish'd? preserve the Gentlemans deare wits Sack I beseech thee.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: You would not lose by it if he ravish you.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: another Song, and direct your voice to this Lady.

LG.L: I'de have her merry, laugh, and smiles
And then look grave and sad:
In every humour but a while,
Make love as 'tis, that's made
I'de have your dresse of sever all shapes,
Like Proteus carv'd, not he,
In humour a she coy Jackanapes
Then a grave Monkey be.
Discourse of all that comes to sence,
But speak none, yet still speak,
No matter here is no offence,
But to speake matter weak.
With thy soft voice sing me asleep,
Then startle me awake,
With Loves notes-passion make me weep,
Then merry for thy sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Jeer. Mi.
SP.P: A discovery?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: What new-found Land?

SP.SPEAKER: Jeer. Mi.
SP.P: The Pigeon that left us hath been in another roome with Mr Formall my Lady Beau∣fields Gentleman Usher, there he sits like the picture of a Harry Soveraigne in a chaire, while she is picking on's pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Fetch him, and his Fairy hither, but for his Mrs sake usher him with loud musick. Ex. Jeer.
Wee'l have some sport. (Flowrish.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter the two Jeerers, and Formall.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Where's the wench?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: The wench has made an escape, she had a glimpse before and suspected me, but here's the wicked Elder.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: What saies my wise▪ Luullus?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Sir, my business was to you, though I met a Remera that is already sunke, I was sent by a Gentlewoman, but no body must know it.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: We heare no business till he have wound up a bottle, and then he shall have audience.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: That's but your fee for entrance, your garnish only; come sir there's no remedy.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: I hope you will conceale it Gentlemen.

LG.L: Why then let us drinke,
Away skurvy thinke,
And do't till we winke;
Which is just to be
So drunke not to see.
First Maudlin to weep,
Then after to sleep;
Why they let us drinke,
And do't till we winke,
Away skurvy' thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: VVhar will become of me? would you and I Lady were in a back roome.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: So now speak my Lord Embassador, I know your soveraign Lady greets us well.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Alas sir, my Lady does not know of my comming; I would speak with you from one that shall be nameless, who thinks you are a debauch'd Gentleman, under the Rose, and desires to talk with you when you are sober: I would be loath to disgrace you before this good company, neither was I willing to tell her what I heard about your drinking and whoring.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: To the point.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: I, I, to the point.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: The principall matter then, and indeed my whole employment at this time to you is—

SP.SPEAKER: New
SP.P: VVhat in the name of circumspection?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: You shall excuse me sir, filence is a vertue; but if you knew who sent me—

SP.SPEAKER: Wen.
SP.P: He would make a costive Statesman.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: It is sufficient one desires to speak with you, I name no time, nor person, I know my office; Mistris Lucy is not to be named at all times.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Mistris Lucie, I am her servant; come drink this narrow sea to her health, you must be drunk insallibly, Ile give a reason; I sweare by Muscadell That I do love her well; come yee Mermaids—

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Ile do you reason then; but is this Mus∣cadell? Mr Newman has sworne; for my own part, Gentlemen, I desire it should go no further.

LG.L: I sweare by Muscadell
That I do love thee well,
And more than I can tell.
By the White, Claret, and Sack
I do love thy Black, black, black,
I do love thy black, black, black.
No Goddesse 'mongst them all
So slender, and so tall,
And gratefull too with all,
Which makes my smews to crack
For thy black, black, black,
For thy dainty black, black.
So lovely, and so faire,
Though shaddow'd with thy haire,
So nimble, just like aire;
All these set me on loves wrack
For thy black, black, black,
For thy dainty black, black.
Thy kind and cunning eye,
When first it did espy,
Our love it did descry,
Dumbe speaking, what d'you lack?
Mine answer'd, thy black, black,
Thy dainty black, black, blacke.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: Excellent!

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Now give Mr Formall his cup.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: I have had the narrow sea, I cannot drink an Ocean.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: His t'other cup; you had my wench as I remember, and Ile prescribe you a pennance; there's another whore for you, drink to her and shee shall pledge.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Give me thy hand, and set thy foor to mine.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: You may trust your single modesty with him.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: For my own part, I had rather do things privately; come kisse me first—here's to thee, my flesh tingles—

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: A word with you two Squiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Wen.
SP.P: Any thing for a shelter, I foresee a storm; and what is one Cat among so many Mastives?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: You are melancholly.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: You lye, you that say nothing lye, if you be of his opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: Me thinks we are very merry.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: We are exceeding merry.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Have you discharg'd your Culvering? where's the paraquito?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: I drunke it off.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: She is vanish'd too.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P:
Then we are our selves, and make me
your example; you know your Province Sirra, make ready for an Angell, sing the designe of ho∣nour, and of fancy. Ex. boy.

LG.HEAD: Song.
LG.L: But first in Phansie we will foole,
Pull off our Dublets, drinke more coole,
Our hats upon our heads not stay,
For each health wee'l throw them away
So Periwig, or Fringe, or Border,
The naked truth wee'l drink in order.
And to the Musick as they play
A Phansie Peece wee'l throw away,
Ʋntill we are drein'd, can draw no more,
And the next day all cry therefore.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Off With Formalls Doublet, off with his Doublet, throw't into the fire, that's a good phan∣sic; now he is Formall right.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: I did not drink hard, for I am cold, the wench would keep me warme, she's a notable fire∣drake; will it please you sir to go to the party?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Now does he betray what a Bawd he would be.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Does no body know where to get a Ser∣pent with two legs that hath never a sting?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: I have a great mind to drink a health in one of my boots.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: I drink no beere glasses, if a shooe will serve turne—

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: His shooe, my scabberd, a match.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: My glove.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Ieer.
SP.P: His cap.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Fill brimmers, every man to his Mistris; now do not I like this phansie.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: We ha don't.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: There's wooll in my scabbard, which is a spungious matter, and when I ha done (Musick Throne descends I may leave my drink behind me, and that's a hanging matter, which I am principally to avoid—Do you heare the Musick of the Spheres Gentle∣men?

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Ieer.
SP.P: From the roofe a Throne?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: This roome is mine, and cald the field of Tempe; Because I woonot stay while (The Wench peeps from under the Table. the Plaies are done when I have a humor to be merry, and drink healths in the clouds, I built this Elisium; and when bright Sack hath crown'd my brow, how soon I am made immortall, you may guesse.

LG.HEAD: A Song in the Throne.
LG.L: As I singing now came down,
I do bring you Bacchus Crown:
From the plumpe Lord of the vine
Clusterd grapes to make you wine,
Your sweld Temples circling in,
Crown'd with this, and bath'd within;
Therefore your best wishes bring,
Place this Garland on your King.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Is not Bacchus the best good fellow God on 'em all? Let me see, Formall shall be King, and he sent to heaven presently.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Send me to heaven? why should I be sent thither before another man?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Ieer.
SP.P: Ret, Ret, verily Ret, here's the Fartridge under the Table.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: They'l be good company, they shall both be immortall together, helpe Gentlemen. Boy you must be depos'd.

SP.SPEAKER: VVench.
SP.P: Alas what shall I doe?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: You shall to heaven Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: VVench.
SP.P: What before my time? and whether I will or no?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: It shall be with as much ease, as if it were in a Featherbed.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Let us sleepe together.

SP.SPEAKER: VVench.
SP.P: Ah pitty a poore Gentlewoman, if you have hearts of flesh, do not use me worse than heathen Prentices.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: So crowne 'm, and give to each a glasse of wine, for a scepter.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Gentlewoman, if we must mount, 'tis none of our seeking, we are but Angells in our owne defence, for my owne part, I desire to go thether in no better company.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Up with 'em, and preserve your scepter glasses, doe not spill your blood royall.

SP.SPEAKER: Wench.
SP.P: Alas, hold there for heavens sake, I must meet three Innes of court Gentlemen at the Stillyard to night, it may be out of my way 20. pound, consider your owne cases.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Peace gentle Queene of grapes.

SP.SPEAKER: Wench.
SP.P: Thou art a traitor too, oh!

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: Doe not jog the chariot, let us take our preserment patiently, and drinke a health to the humble mortalls, that turne up their whites to us, this is pretty high drinking.

SP.SPEAKER: Wench.
SP.P: Drunkards, divells? oh that I were up∣on earth agen.—

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Jeer.
SP.P: Is this the Gentlewomans wine, or water?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Jeer.
SP.P: He mounts insensibly.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: They have a heavenly time on't; you know me sirra.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Noble Mr. Newman.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: There's for your attendance.

SP.SPEAKER: Jeer.
SP.P: What's to pay?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: They shall pay you the reckoning in the other world, you know the back way thither; come my boyes to the departed, having paid all rites
We now returne.

SP.SPEAKER: Jeerers.
SP.P: Like woefull Adamites.

DIV1.HEAD: Act. V. Scaena. I.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter Simpleton, James, (little Table set out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: IAm resolved, since faire meanes can∣not prevaile with Mistris Lucy, to steale her away, this is the key of the back-gate o'th' garden, to the fields, be ready when I give the signe to hurry her into the coach, and when I have her at my Countrey-House, Ile take in her maiden towne, upon my owne composition.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: You wo'not ravish her.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: There are twenty wayes to deale with a woman, and never ravish her; no, I have plaid the foole too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: I am of your opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: But she shall find if I get possession.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: The Coachman is a lusty fellow too, and will help to clap her abroad; the curtaines being close she cannot be heard, and the horses will runne, as the devill were in the poope, for he drives like a Tamberlaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Holla ye pamperd Jades.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: One Traitour more were not amisse for al that.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Thou saist right, for though she be a little woman, her voyce may be too strong for us.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: Let us alone, mind your owne part.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Be resolute James. —Exit Simp.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: The course I am in, hath brought some men to the Gallowes, and doe I take it for pre∣vention?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.P: What desperate fellow's that?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: I am weary of wine and noise, is there no other cure for melancholly? I doe not love the cramp in my necke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: He lookes like a Gentleman that were in debt; my friend doe you come hither to finde a tree? th'art a proper fellow, dost want employment, for though your cloathes have a good glosse, they looke as they were ill lin'd, they want money.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: I suffer that which made the old woman mend her pace fir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: Doe as Ile direct thee.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Whom doe you serve?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.P: I serve my selfe; my Master is a foole; did you never heare of Simpleton?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: That worshipfull puppy?

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.P: He knowes him. I have seen you before, but 'tis no matter where; I like thy countenance; can'st keepe counsell? walke o'this hand o'me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Nay a little further Mistris Lucy, it seemes Mrs Ʋoluble told him no great good fortune, she saw it in his starres, for you know she weares A∣strology at her apron strings; but she told me in private who should be the man, your deere En∣dymion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Who I beseech you?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: The object is presented, and 'tis in vaine to oppose the Constellations, what must be must be, and there were no more Ladyes in the world, I am the man.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: To steale her away?

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: My Master is resolv'd. They are here; close.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: She is betraid.—

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Now.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Help; theeves.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.P: Stop her mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Then every man take his chance.

DIV1.STAGE: (He strikes downe Simpleton. Lucy runs eff.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: Murther, murther.

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: Are you so cunning sir? you shall along with us. (They dis∣arme New.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Worried by Hedghogs!

SP.SPEAKER: Ja.
SP.P: Are you not kill'd outright sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sim.
SP.P: I am not certaine, be sure you hold him fast; to the next Justice; I must get a Surgeon. You are my rivall, I know you well enough, if I miscarry, it shall cost me a hundred pound, but Ile ha thee hang'd for't. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: I understand you perfectly Mistris Voluble, and like your proposition; but a word more of the widdow that is at your' house, shee is very rich you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Not in understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Tis the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Her's all your worship must promise her, to be knighted, for she hath a great mind to bee a Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: I know where a blanck lies dormant for a Baronet, it will carry more noise and authority on the bench too.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: You have done me some discourtesie here tofore, in beleeving the complaints of Intempe∣rate tongues against me, but you see my charity I desire to live in your worships faire opinion a neighbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: I will make you amends sweet Mistris V¦luable, y'are a vertuous Gentlewoman on my con¦science: but how shall this widdow be wrought?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P:
Thats done already. The truth is she in∣quir'd
of me, (for we women use to open our se∣crets one to another) for some stayd Gentleman that was a Lawier, (because she has so great an e∣state, and many sutes to follow) on whom shee might bestow her selfe, for the security of her for∣tune, and I have already prepared her, and such a commendation of your person, and learned gra∣vity, a Justice of Peace and Quorum, out of my private respects to you, without desire or expecta∣tion of any bribe or reward.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: I understand that very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: I know you doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: How much I am bound to your vertue?

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: The widdow has a great mind to see you, but I will contrive it for your honour, shee shall come hither, as to her learned Counsell.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: The invincible wit of a woman! how I honour it.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: There can bee no losse in't if you get a Chaplaine in readinesse, widowes are taken in the opportunitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Rich.
SP.P: A Gentleman brought to be examined, that has wounded one Master Simpleton.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Simpleton? that's the widowes son.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: Richard, send to the Curate of the Parish, say I would speake with him presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Alas who hurt you?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: My rivall Master Newman, Is this the ustice?

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P:
A former quarrell; if you die, I have aw
enough to make it murther, for your good Mo∣thers sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: Cannot you make it manslaughter, and let me live? for I desire but his death.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Hee shall make it what you please. This Gentleman is to bee Knighted, and loves your mother above all the world, things meet as close, as if they went to engender.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: My Mother is worth six thousand pound, if you will promise to make her a Lady, and doe your best to hang the Gentleman, you shall be my Father in Law, when my Landlady sayes the word.

SP.SPEAKER: Vol.
SP.P: Sir Ile take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: Sweet Mistris Voluble, leave your friend to me, I understand the matter perfectly, and it shall goe hard, but wee will have all the Law on our side. Call in the offender; please you sit; Ri∣chard be ready with your Ammunition, Pen, Inke and Paper.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Surgeon, Newman, Iames, Coachman, Constable and officers.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: VVhat is your name sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Surg.
SP.P: My name is Seare.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: He is the Surgeon sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: Ile teach you o follow your profession sirra, Ile make you an example to all Phleboto∣mers; how often have you beene indited for letting of blood firra?

SP.SPEAKER: Sur.
SP.P: I understand you nor.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P:
But I understand you sirra; how durst you vi & armis, felloniously assault this noble Gentle∣man in contempt of peice, and the Kings Law,
his Crowne and dignity? answer me sirra to that. Ile seeze him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sur.
SP.P: You VVorship is mistaken, I never see the Gentleman before, I was sent for—

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.P: He is the Surgeon sir, that is come to take measure of my Masters wounds, it was that Gent∣leman that let him blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: VVhy do they not change faces then? away you knave, and looke to the Gentleman; you stand idling here to stumble authority with a fel∣lonious countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ia.
SP.P: Let us be for sworne both in a tale.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Sir, you are one that should doe Justice; where is my poore friend? bee not so much de∣jected, you did but rescue me sir from disho∣nour.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: I was in a melancholly humour; 'tis come about as the wise woman concluded.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: VVher's Simpleton? I may accuse him for a Rape.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: Take heede what you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Or some such black intent; this Gentle∣man but interpos'd to save me from their surie, and with his sword punish'd a bold offender by letting out some blood that was corrupted.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: Thats not materiall; will you confesse you wounded Master Simpleton? come to the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: I confesse it sir, but heare the reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P:
I will heare no reason, that were simple justice; take him aside, and you may follow your
businesse. Stay young Gentlewoman, I must exa∣mine you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Shall I withdraw, and shut the doore?

DIV1.STAGE: Exeunt all but Iustice and Lucie.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: VVhat Justice ir, or Law is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: It is not Polton, Crompton, nor Fitzerhert, A Justice ought to have some discretion without booke, especially in these cases. I grant you are the root and cause of this misfortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: I ir?

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: Be wise, and understand me; nd being in∣dued with such gifts of nature, native beauty and favour, (come a little nearer) and you to abuse your selfe—

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: How sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: Or suffer your selfe to be abused (come a little nearer) is not to be thankefull for those ex∣cellent benefits.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: VVill you translate an Insolence in others upon my guilt?

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: You accuse an honest Gentleman for an intent of rape; alas poore soule, it was pure af∣fection in him, hee would have ravished you no doubt, with your owne consent, the fault was your Ingratitude, (a little nearer) Seneca doth write much of Ingratitude, that I may come (a little nearer) or else Nero had not let him blood, (yet nearer) this Nero was a most wicked Tyrant, for all he could play upon a fidle, make ballads, and sing them himselfe, and therefore take heede of cruelty, and be gentle, he kissth her. or, sweet-heart Nero died a violent death.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: My Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Lucy you made haste.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Your pardon Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: I understand she is a Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: In the defence of my owne vertue, and the noble Gentleman that suffers for his charity to me—

SP.SPEAKER: Beauf.
SP.P: I came to assist you. It were an injurie to doubt your justice. My name is Beaufield. If my credit may be interpos'd security for New∣man my daughters knowledge in the cause will Enter Clarke. give a most cleare satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: Richard, call in the delinquent, this Lady has spoken very much to the matter, as I under∣stand it. Has the Surgeon done yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: They are comming downe.

DIV1.STAGE: Entr Surgeon, Newman, Simpleton, Iames, Constable, Officers.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: Now sir, how many of his wounds are mortall?

SP.SPEAKER: Sur.
SP.P: There is not one considerable, the Gen∣tleman is in no danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: But have not you authority to hang him? Ile take my oath, he had an intent to kill me. My Lady and Mistris Lucie? Iames, Ile stay no lon∣ger, since I am not mortally wounded, sneake af∣ter me.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: My hanging it is over, and the witch∣craft, I am now my selfe again, if you can pardon Enter Manley. me Madam this too great an honour to your worthlesse servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: How now? what saucie fellow's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Shee's here too. I am bold Cozen to visit you, they say, ther's a Gentleman brought before you, for breach o'th' peace, I come to baile him.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: We take no forrainers; what outlandish thing are you, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: You know me sir, my name is Manley, you cald me cozen yesterday.

SP.SPEAKER: Lust.
SP.P: I never saw you before. I know that name, and a Gentleman that ownes it, a kinsman of mine too, but he is no such Brandemart. Richard, doe you know this Mahound? he calls himselfe my cozen Manly.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Why in this habit?

SP.SPEAKER: Iust
SP.P: Transmigration?

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Is it not some spie ir?

SP.SPEAKER: Iust
SP.P: Constable take him to your charge. Ile teach you sirra, to usurpe a Gentlemans name; tis fello∣ny ipso facto, write his mittimus.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: By what statute? Trigesimo Secundo of King Phillip? I doe not Madam desire your cerificate.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Y'ar a stranger sir to me, yet I dare bee engag'd for his forth comming, hee has an honest face.

SP.SPEAKER: Man
SP.P: Come hither Richard, theres halfe a peece, rub thy eyes woo't, are they open yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P:
I see you plainely now ir, y'are my Ma∣sters
cozen, 'tis Master Manley.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: 'Tis your best course to owne me too; is it so long since you tooke bribes, since you divided and manumisd a crooked chambermaid that robd her Mistris of old Gold? there was a Lancepresa∣do stript a hedge, when you were out of Linnen; Peuter has been left at the back-doore, when you did study Alchymie; I leave the tricke you shew'd the Sailors wife in your Closet, when you pro∣mis'd a reprieve to her goodman from Wapping; I know not that you have run your wither'd mot∣ley face into a premnire; doe not know me, why d'ee no charge the constable?

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: What is a Justice without eyes, I meane spectacles? 'tis he indeed, I understand, and see him perfectly; welcome, a Chaire for my Co∣sen?

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: So then. Madam a word with you, I'le make you know me too, ere I ha' done.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: There is a matted Chamber & a Couch—More businesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Vere is de matre Justice? begar dey have put de sheare upon me, me expect de rish vidow, and have marry the chambermaid, she confesse dat, Maitre Justice, pray take her to your selfe, me desire your varrant, for Metresse Ʋoluble, dat she bring the vidow Simplaton to marry me sans ceremoine, dat is your commissi∣on, or begar me complaine of you to de King.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Did you expect the rich widow Simple∣ton? h, ha! I know this trifle, my Clarke knowes her better

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Bergar Matre Justice, and Matre Clarke make your division, dat is all you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Nice.
SP.P: Sir I have onely cause to complaine, he told me he was a French Lord, Mistris Ʋoluble shall make affidavit, and courted me to be his Lady, and now we are married, he proves but a cinquepace. I look'd for thousands per annum, and he is but one, two, three, foure, and five.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: How, did he pretend himselfe to be a Lord? 'tis Scandalum Magnatum in the highest degree: and by a statute quinquagesimo of the Queene, if she prosecute, he is to be whip'd, and lose his eares three severall market dayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: How will you divide his Eares into three equall portions?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Me give a de whip, and me Iose a mine 'ares!

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: You heare the law, if I complaine.

SP.SPEAKER: I. Ieer.
SP.P: Sir—Mistris Ʋoluble—

SP.SPEAKER: Iu.
SP.P: Is the widow come?

SP.SPEAKER: I Ieer.
SP.P: The Gentlewoman is come, and de∣sires to speake with your worship in private.

SP.SPEAKER: Cla.
SP.P: The Curat's in the Hall sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Iu.
SP.P: So, so, I must intreate your patience for a few minutes; how I am blest! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Tell a me de trot, have you no Argent, no portion?

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: But I have a trade.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: I dare be sworne thou hast.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P:
Aw dat is someting, here is my hand, you no tell a de tale, a me, and me keepe your Enter Sir William, and Mother.
secret by my trot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: I tooke boldnesse Madam upon sight of your Ladiships new Coach at the doore, to entrude and present a poore forsaken servant; give you joy of your old fashion'd young Gentle∣man.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Your companion wants no antiquity, if she have no Visard on.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: I hope you are not married Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: The matters done, and tis more honourable to make a Lady than to marry one. Does any body know this Gentlewoman, she was a widow till this morning, and a rich one I thanke my staires, and wants the subtile art, some Ladyes have to make themselves ridiculous, by doting upon anticks.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: What name has your most reverend Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: She was called the wealthy widow of old Simpleton, before I married her.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: What Is't makes you so merry Mounsieur?

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Begar some body make arrant asse of de Knight, hold a me, or me shall cracke a my rib wi'de laugh, dat is no Simplaton, but an autre Chambermaid, de servant to my vife, begar he be sheated too.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: I must confesse she waited upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Ma foy dat is certaine, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: I desie her, that was but a plot.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P:
Begar it was very fine a plot, me have
patience, dat dere be more foole in de come∣dy.

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Mistris Ʋoluble can justifie what I am, that I am, or would I might nere be, a Lady, and I be'nt, that I be'nt.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: I will have Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: You may have him sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Iustice
SP.P: The reason of this noyse my right worshipfull?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: Give me a warrant presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Iu.
SP.P: Against whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: Ʋolble, I'le have her whip'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Iu.
SP.P: Wrong not the vertuous Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: Vertuous? vexation.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: Why doe you take on so, o' my consci∣ence she is honest enough; does this woman looke like a whore?

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: I thanke you Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: She has gravity enough to be a bawde, and then the worst is past.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: Is not the widow weight, not perfect sterling?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: This is not the widow.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: What widow?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: The rich widow Simpleton.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: I doe believe it, did she promise you marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir VVil.
SP.P: The devills proctor Mistris Ʋoluble made me believe so.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P:
Doe not wrong I say agen that vertuous Gentlewoman Mistris Ʋoluble, I know her, and know her vertuous, but the rich widow Simpleton, you talke of (thankes be to providence) is
newly married, the Priest hath scarce wip'd his oraculous lips, since they pronounc'd us, Man Enter Ʋoluble, and two Ieerers (at one doore) Simpleton, at the other.) and Wife, in my stone Parlour, in good faith la, she's here, her owne tongue will confirme it Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Why does she veile her face.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: It is her modesty, to hide her blushes, that I should so soone prevaile upon her: and thus the morning breakes out of the cloudes.

SP.SPEAKER: impl.
SP.P: By your leave Landlady, wher's my mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Mistris Ʋoluble?

SP.SPEAKER: Moth.
SP.P: Here's my son, he shall be a witnesse I am his mother, I am married to this Knight, and they would perswade me out of my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: 'Tis come about agen, Is this your mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: I have asked her blessing in my dayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: There is no remedy, 'twas your owne Curate did it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ieer
SP.P: Give you joy Mr. Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: Conspiracy, is there no law for this?

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Yes, yes, the canon law, and you must keepe her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: Let me obtaine Madam your faire con∣struction, Sir William you are sped to your desires, and you are fitted Mounsieur Galliard, but Nice, the Jewells must returne to their right owner.

SP.SPEAKER: Gal.
SP.P: Excuse a moy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.P: It must be so, I keepe my wedding ring for thee sweet heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P:
I aske you pardon sir, and Mistris Lucy,
I had a plot upon your loves, to endeare young Simpleton, in hope your credulous nature, to avoid melancholy, might have beene engag'd to some licentious rudenesse, and so made your self unworthy of her affection, but here I must con∣fesse I have no skill in starres nor fortune telling, and am but one among the rest that have de∣ceiv'd your easy faith, forgive me, as I wish you may thrive in your affections.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: I am confirm'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Beau.
SP.P: Nay then let marriages goe round, with this take both possession of my heart and fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Man.
SP.P: You but inlarge my power to doe you service.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Your love, and joyes be constant. Mr. Iustice you must embrace Mistris Ʋoluble.

SP.SPEAKER: Iu.
SP.P: VVell, I will love thee for thy wit; but no more wandring.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋol.
SP.P: You wholly sir shall steere me, and to invite more welcome from you sir, I have not liv'd upon the common charity, I have a state is not to be despis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P: Saist thou so, wee'l put our stocks to∣gether and live merrily.

SP.SPEAKER: New.
SP.P: Will they not take his word? alas poore Formall, there, there's their ransome, bid the whore be honest, I'le plead his reconcilement to my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Ieere Ma.
SP.P: I am gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: But d'ee heare, must I ha' no wench, at the end of the play? that have taken all this paines? what will you doe with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Iust.
SP.P:
Well remembred, this Lady did accuse
him; though I miss'd of the Mother, I will make sure of the son, make his warrant for New∣gate presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: How Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Clark.
SP.P: I know how very well Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: You call'd it love before, I freely pardon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Wil.
SP.P: Let this Day be consecrate to peace, and Hymen.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: And the Night to Ʋenus; let it be so, and thanke this Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Simp.
SP.P: I thanke you all, and will never trust a witch for your sake, I'le goe seeke out my wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: Let no man part, so many hearts here tid'd,
Stay till we drinke a health to every Bride.
